<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="Content" --><h1><div id=bigpic><img src="icons/2/fc1.jpg"/></div>Study With Us</h1>
<h2>English Department Courses</h2>
<p>For information on studying English at UCL, please follow the links 
below. </p>
<h3><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/" target="_blank"> 
UCL Department of English</a></h3>
<ul class="lowermenuheader">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english" target="_blank">BA Course in English Language and Literature</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-english-linguistics" target="_blank">MA Course in English Linguistics</a></li>
</ul>
<p align=center><iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9ps0QBIOJG8" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe></p>
<h3>See also</h3>
<ul class="lowermenuheader">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/taught/degrees/english-linguistics-ma" target="_blank">English Linguistics MA Prospectus</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate" target="_blank">UCL Postgraduate Prospectus</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate" target="_blank">UCL Undergraduate Prospectus</a></li>
</ul>
            <!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<p><a href="https://twitter.com/UCLEnglishUsage" class="twitter-follow-button" data-show-count="false" data-dnt="true">Follow @UCLEnglishUsage</a>

            </li>

                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate">Postgraduate</a>
                
            </li>
        </ul>
    </nav>

                    <!--endnoindex-->
                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Postgraduate</h1>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/pg-timetable-autumn-2017">Postgraduate Timetable Autumn 2017</a></li>
<li><a href="/silva/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/Timetable_Spring-2018_MA_Provisional" target="_self">Postgraduate Timetable Spring 2018 (Provisional)<br /></a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/MA_Handbook_2017-18" target="_self">Handbook:  MA Programmes</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/Research_Degree_Handbook_2017-18" target="_self">Handbook:  MPhil/PhD</a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">MA English:  Issues in Modern Culture</h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/Issues_ReadingList_2017-18" target="_self">MA Issues Reading List 2017-18</a></li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
</ul>

<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading">Shakespeare in his Time module offered as part of the MA Early Modern Studies:</h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/early-modern-studies-ma" target="_self">MA Early Modern Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/shakespeare-iht-seminar-programme-2017">Shakespeare In His Time Seminar Schedule (15 credit module, 2017)</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/Shakespeare_in_his_time_reading-2018">Shakespeare In His Time Reading List 2018</a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">General</h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.grad.ucl.ac.uk/societies/english-department-society.html" target="_self">English Department Graduate Society</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/moveable-type" target="_self"><em>Moveable Type </em>Graduate Journal</a><em><br /></em></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah/figs">The Faculty Institute for Graduate Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/style_sheet_for_essays">Essay Style Sheet (Word)</a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Research Seminar Series Programme</h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/postgraduate/documents/research-seminar-series-autumn-2017">Research Seminar Series Autumn 2017<br /></a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Extenuating Circumstances</h2>





<p class="p">For the UCL Extenuating Circumstances Claim Form, see the<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/srs/academic-manual/c4/annexes" target="_self"> annexes of Chapter 4 of the UCL Academic Manual</a>. In addition, it is important to read <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/srs/academic-manual/c4/extenuating-circumstances" target="_self">Chapter 4, Section 6.2 of the UCL Academic Manual </a>before completing the form. <br /> <br />Postgraduate students should hand completed claim forms, 
together with any evidence, to Clare Stainthorp in the English Department 
Office (within one week of the circumstance concerned).</p>

<h2 class="heading">Moodle</h2>





<p class="p">All relevant programme information will be available via <a href="https://moodle.ucl.ac.uk/login/" target="_blank">Moodle</a>. </p>

<h2 class="heading">See also</h2>





<p class="p">Some important UCL sources of information are listed below.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/staff/term-dates/2016-2017" target="_self">UCL Term Dates</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.grad.ucl.ac.uk/" target="_self">UCL Doctoral School</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/support-pages" target="_blank">UCL Online Student Support</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/disability/" target="_blank">UCL Information for Students with a Disability</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/" target="_blank">UCL Information for Prospective Students</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/international-students/" target="_blank">UCL Information for International Students</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/download" target="_self">UCL Postgraduate Prospectus</a></li>
</ul>

    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {

<h1 class="heading">Undergraduates</h1>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">New Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/new-students" target="_self">UCL New Students website</a></li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Course Units</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"></p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/course_units_17-18" target="_self">Information for full-degree undergraduate students of other UCL departments who wish to apply to take a course in the English Department</a> </p>
<p class="p"></p>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/foster-court-sign" width="240" height="160" alt="Foster Court Sign" class="medium-image" title="Foster Court Sign" /><p class="p"></p>
<p class="p"></p>
<p class="p"></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Undergraduate Handbook 2017-18</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>

<h2 class="heading">English Department Undergraduate Handbook </h2>





<ul class="nobullet">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/undergraduate_handbook_17-18"><strong>Undergraduate Handbook 2017-18</strong></a><br />
</li>
</ul>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/observatory_snow" width="120" height="184" alt="Observatory in snow, UCL Main Quad" class="no-respond float-right" title="Observatory in snow, UCL Main Quad" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">BASc students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">First-year
UCL BASc students can take the designated half-unit ‘Introduction to English
Literature’ (ENGL1004) as part of the BASc ‘Cultures’ pathway. This is examined
by two final essays, but there are no additional tutorial essays to write (and
first-year BASc students are not part of the English Department personal tutor
system). </p>
<p class="p">Much
information about the course, and the assessment, is to be found on the course
Moodle page for ENGL1004. </p>
<p class="p">BASc
students who achieve a mark of 60 or more in each of the two assessed essays
for ENGL1004 can continue in subsequent years to take full-year courses (one or
more, depending on their degree structure) along side second-and final-year BA
English and Modern Language Plus students. </p>
<p class="p">Continuing
BASc students receive one tutorial per term with a personal tutor (in the
autumn and spring terms) for each of their English courses. One essay is
written for each tutorial; these are a requirement for the course, though
tutorial essay marks do not contribute to the final assessment for the course.
Second/Final Year BASc students will find information relevant to them in Part
1 of the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/ug_handbook_english_16-17">Undergraduate Handbook</a>, and should also refer to
the ‘Guidance on Examinations 2016-17’ and ‘Style Sheet for Essays’ documents
in the appendices.</p>
<p class="p">BASc
students do not have the option of writing a Course Essay in the place of a
desk exam. </p>
<p class="p">The
English Department BASc Tutor (who convenes the ENGL1004 course) is Dr Victoria
Symons. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Timetables</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>

<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading">First Year Course </h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/1_yr_timetable-aut17" target="_self"><strong>Timetable for Autumn Term 2017</strong></a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Second and Third Year Courses</h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/2_3_yr_timetable-aut17" target="_self">Timetable for Autumn Term 2017</a><br /></strong></li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Punctuation Guide</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> This guide aims to explain the basic rules of punctuation, and to 
help undergraduates to avoid some of the most common errors. It is intended
 as a rapid reference tool and is by no means exhaustive. <br /></p>
<p class="p">For more 
detailed explanations students are advised to look at <strong><em>Fowler’s Modern English Usage</em></strong>.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/punctuation-guide-with-excercises">punctuation-guide</a></li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Style Sheet</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/style_sheet_for_essays"> Download the Style Sheet for Essays<strong> </strong></a></li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Examinations and Long Essays</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Please see the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/accordion/handbooks">Undergraduate Handbook 2016-17</a> for important information about the examinations, including the departmental 'Guidance on Examinations 2016-17' (in Appendix 3).<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/exam_descriptions_2017" target="_self">Examination Descriptions 2017</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/research-essay-cover-sheet-2016-17">Research Essay Cover Sheet 2016-17</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/course-essay-cover-sheet-2016-17">Course Essay Cover Sheet 2016-17</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/accordion/stylesheet">Style Sheet for Essays</a></li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/accordion/plagiarism-declaration-forms">Plagiarism declaration form</a></li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/library" target="_self">Examination past papers for 2nd and 3rd years </a><em>(Link to UCL Library)</em></li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li><strong>BA English first-year Sessional Examination past papers are available from the first-year course Moodle page<br /></strong>
</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"> Extenuating Circumstances Form: 
</h2>





<p class="p"><strong> </strong>For the UCL Extenuating Circumstances Claim Form, see the<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/srs/academic-manual/c4/annexes" target="_self"> annexes of Chapter 4 of the UCL Academic Manual</a>. In addition, it is important to read <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/srs/academic-manual/c4/extenuating-circumstances" target="_self">Chapter 4, Section 6.2 of the UCL Academic Manual </a>before completing the form. <br /></p>
<p class="p">Undergraduate students should hand completed claim forms, together with any evidence, to Anita Garfoot in the English Department Office (within one week of the circumstance concerned).<br /></p>

<h2 class="heading"> </h2>

<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/2014-15-exam-reports">Second and Third Year examinations 2015</a></li>

</ul>

</div>
  </dd>

<h3 class="heading"></h3>

<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
   
  

<h3 class="heading">UCL+</h3>





<p class="p">Register your interest in studying at the Faculty of Arts &amp; Humanities and 
receive information about open days, applications, and more.</p>
<p class="clearfix">
 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest"
    class="cta btn pull-left"
    onclick="_gaq.push(['_trackEvent','CTA','Click','http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest'])">

   Register your interest

 </a>
</p>

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;

  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");

    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Undergraduate Handbook 2017-18</h1>

<h2 class="heading">English Department Undergraduate Handbook </h2>





<ul class="nobullet">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/undergraduate_handbook_17-18"><strong>Undergraduate Handbook 2017-18</strong></a><br />
</li>
</ul>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current-students/undergraduate/documents/observatory_snow" width="120" height="184" alt="Observatory in snow, UCL Main Quad" class="no-respond float-right" title="Observatory in snow, UCL Main Quad" />

<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">

<h3 class="heading"></h3>






<h3 class="heading"></h3>






<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
   
  

<h3 class="heading">UCL+</h3>





<p class="p">Register your interest in studying at the Faculty of Arts &amp; Humanities and 
receive information about open days, applications, and more.</p>
<p class="clearfix">
 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest"
    class="cta btn pull-left"
    onclick="_gaq.push(['_trackEvent','CTA','Click','http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest'])">

   Register your interest

 </a>
</p>


</section>

</div>

<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/selcs/study/moodle" width="450" height="287" alt="Moodle" class="medium-image" title="Moodle" />

  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;

    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";

  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();

<h3 class="heading"></h3>






<h3 class="heading"></h3>






<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--bar-thin">
  
   
  

<h3 class="heading">UCL+</h3>





<p class="p">Register your interest in studying at the Faculty of Arts &amp; Humanities and 
receive information about open days, applications, and more.</p>
<p class="clearfix">
 <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest"
    class="cta btn pull-left"
    onclick="_gaq.push(['_trackEvent','CTA','Click','http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/register-your-interest'])">

   Register your interest

 </a>
</p>


</section>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Punctuation Guide</h1>
<p class="p"> This guide aims to explain the basic rules of punctuation, and to 
help undergraduates to avoid some of the most common errors. It is intended
 as a rapid reference tool and is by no means exhaustive. <br /></p>
<p class="p">For more 
detailed explanations students are advised to look at <strong><em>Fowler’s Modern English Usage</em></strong>.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Clauses" target="_self">Independent and dependent clauses </a></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Conjunctions" target="_self">Conjunctions</a> </strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#CoordConj" target="_self">Coordinating Conjunctions</a></li>
<li> <a href="#SubordConj" target="_self">Subordinating Conjunctions</a></li>
<li> <a href="#ConjAdv" target="_self">Conjunctive Adverbs</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Commas" target="_self">Commas </a></strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#ListCommas" target="_self">Listing Commas</a></li>
<li> <a href="#JoinCommas" target="_self">Joining Commas</a></li>
<li> <a href="#BrackCommas" target="_self">Bracketing Commas</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Dash" target="_self">Dashes </a></strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#BrackDash" target="_self">Bracketing Dashes</a></li>
<li> <a href="#Afterdash" target="_self">The Afterthought Dash</a></li>
<li> <a href="#ExplanDash" target="_self">The Explanatory Dash</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Brackets" target="_self">Brackets (parentheses)</a> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Semicolons" target="_self">Semicolons </a></strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#JoinClauses" target="_self">Joining Related Independent Clauses </a></li>
<li> <a href="#ComplexLists" target="_self">Complex lists</a></li>
<li> <a href="#PreConjAdv" target="_self">Preceding Conjunctive Adverbs (however, nevertheless, etc.)</a></li>
<li> <a href="#PreCoordConj" target="_self">Preceding Coordinating Conjunctions (and, but, etc.)</a></li>
<li> <a href="#Misuses" target="_self">Common Misuses</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Colons" target="_self">Colons </a></strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#IntroColon" target="_self">Colon of Introduction</a></li>
<li> <a href="#ExplanColon" target="_self">Colon of Explanation</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#Exercises" target="_self">Punctuation Exercises </a></strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="#ClausesEX" target="_self">Independent and Dependent Clauses Exercise</a></li>
<li> <a href="#CommaEX" target="_self">Comma Exercise</a></li>
<li> <a href="#SemicolonEX" target="_self">Semicolon Exercise</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Clauses"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> Independent and Dependent Clauses </strong></p>
<p class="p">   The ability to identify independent and dependent clauses is an 
important part of understanding how to punctuate your sentences 
correctly (particularly in the cases of the <a href="#Commas" target="_self"><strong>comma</strong></a> and the <a href="#Semicolons" target="_self"><strong>semicolon</strong></a>).</p>
<p class="p">   An independent (or main) clause contains a subject and verb, and 
forms a complete meaning in itself (i.e., it could stand alone as a 
complete sentence).</p>
<p class="p">   A dependent (or subordinate) clause does not form a complete meaning
 and cannot stand alone; it needs an independent clause to complete its 
meaning.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   In the following sentences, the independent clause or clauses are marked <strong>[i]</strong> while dependent clauses are marked <strong>[d]:</strong></p>
<p class="p">   ‘The gardener had been up since dawn<strong> [i]</strong>, mowing the lawns and sweeping them <strong>[d 1]</strong>, until the grass and the dark flat rosettes where the daisy plants had been seemed to shine <strong>[d 2]</strong>.’</p>
<p class="p">   Katherine Mansfield, ‘The Garden Party’ (1922) in <em>The Collected Stories</em> (London: Penguin, 2001), 245.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Although there is little explicit reference to Elizabeth in Shakespeare’s works <strong>[d]</strong>, over a long period scholars have sought her there in veiled or encoded forms<strong> [i]</strong>.’</p>
<p class="p">   Helen Hackett, <em>Shakespeare and Elizabeth: The Meeting of Two Myths </em>(Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2009), 112.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘One very sunny afternoon Sophie went inside for her piano lesson<strong> [i 1]</strong>, and Mary remained seated on the grass<strong> [i 2]</strong>.’</p>
<p class="p">   Jane Bowles, <em>Two Serious Ladies</em> (1943; London: Virago, 1979), 5.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> Note:</strong> In many instances, such as the second example from Helen Hackett, it is the <a href="#SubordConj" target="_self"><strong>subordinating conjunction</strong></a>
 that makes the clause subordinate, or dependent (i.e., if this word was
 taken away the clause would be independent). On the other hand, <a href="#CoordConj" target="_self"><strong>coordinating conjunctions</strong></a> (as in the last example from Jane Bowles), and <strong><a href="#ConjAdv" target="_self">conjunctive adverbs</a> </strong>(however, therefore, etc.), do not make independent clauses dependent.</p>
<p class="p"><strong><a href="#ClausesEX" target="_self">Clauses Exercise</a></strong><br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Conjunctions"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> Conjunctions </strong></p>
<p class="p">   As their name suggests, conjunctions are used to connect words and phrases.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="CoordConj"></a><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Coordinating Conjunctions</strong> </p>
<p class="p">   Coordinating conjunctions can be used to join individual words (‘pen <em>and</em> paper’). They can also connect <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent</strong></a> clauses:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘The doors stood open, breathing out incense <em>and</em> heavy soul, <em>and</em>
 the spirit was that of the market scene in the pantomime when the cast,
 encouraged by the audience, has let the business get out of hand.’</p>
<p class="p">   Penelope Fitzgerald, <em>Offshore </em>(1979; London: Flamingo, 2003), 148.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘She loved not the savour of tar nor of pitch,<br /> <em>Yet </em>a tailor might scratch her where'er she did itch.’</p>
<p class="p">   William Shakespeare, <em>The Tempest</em> (1611; London: Arden Shakespeare, 2001), 2.2.51-2.</p>
<p class="p"> <em> </em></p>
<p class="p"> <em> List of coordinating conjunctions: </em></p>
<p class="p">   And</p>
<p class="p">   But</p>
<p class="p">   For</p>
<p class="p">   Or</p>
<p class="p">   So</p>
<p class="p">   Yet</p>
<p class="p">   Either…or</p>
<p class="p">   Neither…nor</p>
<p class="p">   Both…and</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Subordinating Conjunctions </strong></p>
<p class="p">   As their name suggests, these can connect subordinate (or <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>dependent</strong></a>) clauses to an <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent</strong></a> clause. </p>
<p class="p"> <br />
  Examples:</p>
<p class="p">  ‘she never showed fatigue, <em>except</em> fatigue of the eyes.’<br />
  Elizabeth Bowen, <em>Death of the Heart </em>(1938; New York: Anchor Books, 2000), 26.</p>
<p class="p">  ‘<em>Though</em> uncertain that any one were to blame, she found fault with every absent friend.’ <br />
  Jane Austen, <em>Sense and Sensibility </em>(1811; London: Penguin, 2003), 333.</p>
<p class="p"> 
‘She was in revolt, <em>until</em> a whisper of the day of bells reduced her to blank submission.’ <br />
George Meredith, <em>The Egoist </em>(1879; London: Penguin, 1968), 134.
<br /> <br />
  Note: In many instances (such as the last example) it is the subordinating conjunction that makes the clause subordinate or <strong><a href="#Clauses" target="_self">dependent</a> </strong>(i.e., if this word were taken away the clause would be <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent</strong></a>). This is not the case with coordinating conjunctions or conjunctive adverbs.<br /> </p>
<p class="p">
  There are many subordinating conjunctions, but here are some common 
ones, grouped according to the relations that they express:<br /> </p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Time (after, before, as, since, until, when, whenever, while)</li>
<li> Place (where, wherever)</li>
<li> Purpose (to, in order to, so that)</li>
<li> Reason (because, since, for)</li>
<li> Exception (except, save that)</li>
<li> Contrast (whereas, whilst, while, although, though)</li>
<li> Condition (if, unless, in case, as long as)</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="ConjAdv"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Conjunctive Adverbs </strong></p>
<p class="p">   A conjunctive adverb indicates the relationship between two 
independent clauses. It differs from other types of conjunctions in 
three important ways:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> It can often be moved to other parts of the clause:</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   ‘<em>However</em>, he thought that he would get away with it’.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘He thought, <em>however</em>, that he would get away with it’.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> If it is placed at the beginning of an independent clause, it must be preceded by a semicolon or full stop, not a comma:</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   ‘He knew that what he did was wrong; <em>nevertheless</em>, he felt no remorse’.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> In almost all cases, a conjunctive adverb should be followed by a comma.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <em> Some common conjunctive adverbs: </em></p>
<p class="p"> <em> </em></p>
<p class="p">   Consequently</p>
<p class="p">   Furthermore </p>
<p class="p">   However</p>
<p class="p">   Meanwhile</p>
<p class="p">   Nevertheless</p>
<p class="p">   Nonetheless</p>
<p class="p">   Therefore</p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Commas"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> Commas </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Please be aware that this is simply a checklist. It is aimed at 
helping one avoid the most common errors that are made when using commas
 and is by no means exhaustive. For a more thorough explanation of 
commas please refer to <em>Fowler’s Modern English Usage</em>.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="ListCommas"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Listing Commas </strong></p>
<p class="p">   The listing comma is used to separate words, phrases or clauses in a list, especially where one could use <em>and</em> or <em>or</em> instead.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘The poet’s mind is in fact a receptacle for seizing and storing up 
numberless feelings, phrases, images, which remain there until all the 
particles which can unite to form a new compound are present together.’</p>
<p class="p">   T.S. Eliot, 'Tradition and the Individual Talent' (1919) in <em>Selected Prose of T.S. Eliot</em> (London: Faber and Faber, 1975), 41.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Neary besieged Miss Counihan with attentions, sending her mangoes, 
orchids, Cuban cigarettes and a passionately autographed copy of his 
tractate, <em>The Doctrine of the Limit</em>.’</p>
<p class="p">   Samuel Beckett, <em>Murphy</em> (1938; London: Faber and Faber, 2009), 34.</p>
<p class="p">   (Please note that some writers would place a comma before the <em>and</em> at the end of a list. This is sometimes called the ‘Oxford Comma’ and is not compulsory.)</p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="JoinCommas"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Joining Commas</strong></p>
<p class="p">   The joining comma is used where two <strong><a href="#Clauses" target="_self">independent clauses</a> </strong>are joined to form one sentence. It must, however, precede the following <a href="#CoordConj" target="_self"><strong>coordinating conjunctions</strong></a>: <em>and</em>, <em>or</em>, <em>but</em>, <em>while</em> and <em>yet</em>. </p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘He must be quite aware of the obvious fact that art never improves, but that the material of art is never quite the same.’</p>
<p class="p">   T.S. Eliot, 'Tradition and the Individual Talent' (1919), 39.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘That is I write books but I am not proud of this any more than 
anyone is of their nails growing, and if it be argued that I was happier
 at this period because I had less free time than most you will be 
wrong’.</p>
<p class="p">   Henry Green, <em>Pack my Bag</em> (1940; London: Vintage, 2000), 154.</p>
<p class="p">   Be aware that there are also <a href="#ConjAdv" target="_self"><strong>conjunctive adverbs</strong></a> which should not follow a joining comma, e.g. <em>therefore</em>, <em>however</em>, <em>consequently</em>, <em>moreover</em>, <em>nevertheless</em>, <em>meanwhile</em>, <em>thus</em> etc. In the latter cases, and in cases where no <a href="#Conjunctions" target="_self"><strong>conjunctions</strong></a> are present, a <a href="#Semicolons" target="_self"><strong>semicolon</strong></a> or a <strong>full stop</strong> should be used.</p>
<p class="p">   Here’s an example where a <a href="#Semicolons" target="_self"><strong>semicolon</strong> </a>is required; to use a comma here would be wrong and is known as a <strong>comma splice</strong>:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘That, none the less, was but a flicker; what made the real difference, as I have hinted, was his mute passage with Maggie.’</p>
<p class="p">   Henry James, <em>The Golden Bowl</em> (1904; London: Penguin, 2001), 148.</p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="BrackCommas"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Bracketing Commas</strong></p>
<p class="p">   Bracketing commas are used to bracket off weak interruptions: insertions, asides or afterthoughts. (<a href="#Dash" target="_self"><strong>Dashes</strong></a> or <a href="#Brackets" target="_self"><strong>brackets</strong></a> may also be used for this.) Check carefully that the bracketed words are really an interruption; it is only <em>non-restrictive</em> (or <em>non-defining</em>) <em>relative clauses</em>
 which require bracketing commas. In these cases the non-restrictive 
clause, which is bracketed by commas, could be removed without 
destroying the sense.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘The anxiety, it was true, would have been, even though not 
imparted, separately shared; for Fanny Assingham’s face was, by the same
 stroke, not at all thickly veiled for him, and a queer light, of a 
colour quite to match, fairly glittered in the four fine eyes of Miss 
Lutches.’</p>
<p class="p">   Henry James, <em>The Golden Bowl</em>, 148.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘His soul swooned slowly as he heard the snow falling faintly 
through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last
 end, upon all the living and the dead.’</p>
<p class="p">   James Joyce, ‘The Dead’ in <em>Dubliners</em> (1914; London: Granada Publishing, 1979), 201.</p>
<p class="p">   Tips and Advice</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Beware the <strong>comma splice</strong>. Do not use a comma to separate two <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent clauses</strong></a> that are not linked by a <a href="#Conjunctions" target="_self"><strong>conjunction</strong></a>; this is the role of the <a href="#Semicolons" target="_self"><strong>semicolon</strong></a> or the <strong>full stop</strong>.</li>
<li> The decision on whether to use a comma that is not absolutely 
essential is a matter of individual style. Just be aware that overuse 
can lead to cluttered or stuttering prose, whereas underuse can make 
prose more difficult for the reader to follow.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#CommaEX" target="_self">Comma Exercise </a></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Dash"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> The Dash </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Since the dash has several uses, each has been given a name to make it easier to distinguish between them.</p>
<p class="p"><a class="index-element" id="BrackDash"></a><br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> Bracketing Dashes </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Like <a href="#Brackets" target="_self"><strong>brackets</strong></a> and <a href="#BrackCommas" target="_self"><strong>bracketing commas</strong></a>,
 this set of two dashes is used to bracket off weak interruptions: 
insertions, asides or afterthoughts. Bracketing dashes should only be 
used if the words enclosed within the two dashes are not grammatically 
or semantically essential to the sentence (i.e., if they were removed 
the sentence would still make sense).</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Most of them clearly – or, in many cases, fuzzily – depicted life in the field.’</p>
<p class="p">   Alan Hollinghurst, <em>The Swimming-Pool Library</em> (1988; London: Vintage, 1998), 95.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘I stood up on the daybed – my finger still holding my place in the 
book – and, stretching to my full height, tried to make out what was 
being said up there and by whom.’</p>
<p class="p">   Philip Roth, <em>The Ghost Writer </em>(New York: Vintage International, 1979), 116.</p>
<p class="p">   In the second example, the interruption is like the finger in the 
book it describes: one allows Roth to keep hold of two ideas in the same
 sentence; the other allows his character to keep his place in a book 
whilst performing an awkward eavesdropping manoeuvre.</p>
<p class="p">   Note: Bracketing dashes tend not to detract from the importance or relevance of the enclosed material as much as <a href="#Brackets" target="_self"><strong>brackets</strong></a>.</p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="Afterdash"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>The Afterthought Dash </strong></p>
<p class="p">   A single dash may be used before an afterthought that occurs at the end of a sentence: </p>
<p class="p">   ‘A London society lady gives her views on not spoiling the servants 
by lending them books “of the wrong kind for their station” and making 
them dissatisfied – “and dreadfully ambitious!” suggests Ethelberta 
slyly.’</p>
<p class="p">   Claire Tomalin, <em>Thomas Hardy: The Time-Torn Man</em> (London: Viking, 2006), 150 </p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="ExplanDash"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>The Explanatory Dash </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">   This dash is used to introduce examples, explanations, elaborations or amplifications: </p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p">   ‘...there were odd items tucked between the pages – postcards, letters, drawings, even hotel bills and visiting cards.’</p>
<p class="p">   Alan Hollinghurst, <em>The Swimming-Pool Library</em>, 95.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘What he writes is based on ideas independently formed – both 
generated and shaped by himself, without either confirmation, challenge,
 or complication from relevant reading.’</p>
<p class="p">   Rachel Bowlby, <em>Freudian Mythologies: Greek Tragedy and Modern Identities</em> (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2007), 30.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Carlyle told Chapman in March that he had received a letter from Dr
 Stamm announcing that he intended to call on him – a letter which made 
Carlyle expect “nothing less than <em>Elijah the Tishbite</em>”, as Marian reported to the Brays.’</p>
<p class="p">   Rosemary Ashton, <em>142 Strand </em>(London: Chatto &amp; Windus, 2006), 177.</p>
<p class="p">   Note: These dashes are doing a similar job to that of the <a href="#Colons" target="_self"><strong>colon</strong></a>, but they tend to be less formal. They can also be less obstructive to the flow of<a href="#Colons" target="_self"></a> the sentence.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> Tips and advice: </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> One advantage of the dash is that it can help to narrow the gap 
between writing and thought processes. By the same token, it can make 
prose seem more natural or conversational. However, excessive or 
inappropriate use of the dash can make writing seem informal and/or 
under-considered.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Brackets"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> Brackets (parentheses) </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Asides</p>
<p class="p">   Brackets introduce or set off a strong or weak interruption (asides,
 afterthoughts, sudden interjections, etc.): something that has a 
bearing on the context of the sentence, but in a purely subordinate way 
(i.e., if it were lifted out the sentence would still be grammatically 
correct).</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘What we call happiness in the strictest sense comes from the 
(preferably sudden) satisfaction of needs which have been dammed up to a
 high degree.’</p>
<p class="p">   Sigmund Freud, 'Civilization and Its Discontents' (1930), <em>The Standard Edition</em>, vol. 21 (London: The Hogarth Press, 1995), 76.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘The evil of the actual disparity in their ages (and Mr Woodhouse 
had not married early) was much increased by his constitution and 
habits;’</p>
<p class="p">   Jane Austen, <em>Emma</em> (1815; Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2005), 5.</p>
<p class="p">   Brackets are often used for enclosing additional information and can carry the meaning of ‘i.e.’ or ‘namely’.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘…his <em>Osenbrigs</em> (a sort of brown <em>Holland</em> suit he had on) cou’d not conceal the Graces of his Looks and Mien;’</p>
<p class="p">   Aphra Behn, <em>Oroonoko; or, The Royal Slave</em> (1688; Boston, MA: Bedford/St. Martin’s Press, 2000), 68.</p>
<p class="p">   Tips and Advice </p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> If brackets are used within a sentence then the full stop should 
come outside of the second bracket. (If the whole sentence is within the
 bracket, then it should remain inside.)</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Semicolons"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> Semicolons </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="JoinClauses"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Joining Related Independent Clauses </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Semicolons are used to join two or more related <strong><a href="#Clauses" target="_self">independent clauses</a> </strong>without linking words (<a href="#Conjunctions" target="_self"><strong>conjunctions</strong></a>). </p>
<p class="p">   Examples: </p>
<p class="p">   ‘Dickens exaggerates and generalizes; Emily Brontë focuses and substantiates the passions.’ </p>
<p class="p">   Barbara Hardy, <em>Forms of feeling in Victorian Fiction </em>(1985; London: Methuen, 1986), 97.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Yet this capital was by no means sufficient to let the family live 
on the interest of it; for one year, perhaps, or at the most two, they 
could live on the principal, that was all.’</p>
<p class="p">   Franz Kafka, ‘The Metamorphosis’ (1915) in <em>Kafka’s ‘The Metamorphosis’ and Other Writings</em>, trans. Volkmar Sander and Daniel Theisen (London: Continuum, 2002), 22.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘The shadows on the perfect lawn were straight and angular; they 
were the shadows of an old man sitting in a deep wicker-chair near the 
low table on which the tea had been served, and of two younger men 
strolling to and fro, in desultory talk, in front of him.’</p>
<p class="p">   Henry James, <em>The Portrait of a Lady</em> (1881; London: Penguin, 2003), 59.</p>
<p class="p">   One of the beauties of the semicolon is that it can allow the writer
 to imply a relationship between two clauses without explicitly 
specifying this relationship. This can make for more suggestive prose; 
it can also encourage more active interpretation on the part of the 
reader. </p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="ComplexLists"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Complex Lists </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Semicolons are often used to separate terms in a list, particularly when these individual terms contain <a href="#Commas" target="_self"><strong>commas</strong></a>. </p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘…these years have seen the reprinting of her novels, which matters; the publication of a Penguin <em>Selected Poems</em>, and of an excellent selection of poetry and prose (by Hermione Lee), which matters more; and the publication of the <em>Collected Poems</em>, which matters most.’ </p>
<p class="p">   Christopher Ricks, ‘Stevie Smith’ in <em>The Force of Poetry</em> (1984; Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002), 255. </p>
<p class="p">   ‘[Pindar’s] complex stanzas were patterned in sets of three: moving 
in a dance rhythm to the left, the chorus chanted the strophe; moving to
 the right, the antistrophe; then, standing still, the epode.' </p>
<p class="p">   M. H. Abrams, <em>A Glossary of Literary Terms</em>, 7 th Edition (London: Harcourt Brace, 1999), 198. </p>
<p class="p">   ‘In people's eyes, in the swing, tramp, and trudge; in the bellow 
and the uproar; the carriages, motor cars, omnibuses, vans, sandwich men
 shuffling and swinging; brass bands; barrel organs; in the triumph and 
the jingle and the strange high singing of some aeroplane overhead was 
what she loved; life; London; this moment of June.’ </p>
<p class="p">   Virginia Woolf, <em>Mrs Dalloway</em> (1925; Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2000), 4. </p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="PreConjAdv"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Preceding Conjunctive Adverbs (however, nevertheless, etc) </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Semicolons are used to join <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent clauses</strong></a> together with the following <strong>conjunctive adverbs</strong>: therefore, however, consequently, moreover, otherwise, nevertheless, meanwhile, thus etc. </p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘In the event, Donne recovered from the sickness that precipitated 
“Hymne to God my God, in my sicknesse”; nevertheless, the poem arises 
from his conviction that he is in the last moments of life about to 
enter the precincts of death.’</p>
<p class="p">   Helen Vendler, <em>Last Looks, Last Books: Stevens, Plath, Lowell, Bishop, Merrill</em> (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2010), 14.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘A system of hypocrisy, which lasts through whole years, is one 
seldom satisfactorily practised by a person of one-and-twenty; however, 
our readers will recollect, that, though young in years, our heroine was
 old in life and experience, and we have written to no purpose if they 
have not discovered that she was a very clever woman.’</p>
<p class="p">   William Makepeace Thackeray, <em>Vanity Fair</em> (1848; Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1998), 111.</p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="PreCoordConj"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Preceding Coordinating Conjunctions (and, but, etc) </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Semicolons can be used to separate two <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent clauses</strong></a>
 with a coordinating conjunction (and, but, yet, or, then, so). As with 
complex lists, this is particularly helpful when there are already a lot
 of <a href="#Commas" target="_self"><strong>commas</strong></a> in the sentence.</p>
<p class="p">   Example:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘In their memories of nursery rhyme and of fairy tale, in their 
lisping and lilting, they are a child’s eye view; yet children don’t 
write poems which matter except as that diminished thing, 
poems-by-children.’ </p>
<p class="p">   Christopher Ricks, ‘Stevie Smith’, 247. </p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="Misuses"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Common Misuses </strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Using a semicolon to join two clauses when one of these is not <a href="#Clauses" target="_self"><strong>independent</strong></a>. </li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Example:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘Dickens created many brilliant comic characters, but Mrs Gamp makes
 me laugh the most; more, even, than cushion-throwing Grandfather 
Smallweed.’</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Using a semicolon where a <a href="#Colons" target="_self"><strong>colon</strong></a> would have been more appropriate.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Example:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘There is one thing you must remember about semicolons and colons; the two are not interchangeable.’</p>
<p class="p">   Here the special conditions which necessitate the use of a <a href="#Colons" target="_self"><strong>colon</strong></a> are present: a premise or introductory statement followed by an answer.</p>
<p class="p">   Note: </p>
<p class="p">   You will probably come across examples of authors who break these 
rules. This is often a result of changes in grammatical conventions over
 time.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘…while engaged in this survey she had made room in it for her 
companions; a comprehensiveness of observation easily conceivable on the
 part of a young woman who was evidently both intelligent and excited.’</p>
<p class="p">   Henry James, <em>The Portrait of a Lady</em>, 72.</p>
<p class="p"> 
‘“Yes,” said she; adding to herself: “Rather mild!”’ <br />
Thomas Hardy, <em>Jude the Obscure</em> (1895; London: Penguin, 1998), 47.
 </p>
<p class="p">   Tips and Advice: </p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> As with most punctuation marks, it is best not to overuse the semicolon.</li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> <strong> <a href="#SemicolonEX" target="_self">Semicolon Exercise</a></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Colons"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> Colons </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="IntroColon"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>The Colon of Introduction</strong></p>
<p class="p">   Colons are used to introduce a list, a quotation or a speech.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘This is conventionally agreed to be true of written language, but 
Derrida argues that it is just as much the condition of spoken language:</p>
<p class="p">   Every sign, linguistic or non-linguistic, spoken or written (in the 
usual sense of this opposition), as a small or large unity, can be <em>cited</em>,
 put between quotation marks; thereby it can break with every given 
context, and engender infinitely new contexts in an absolutely 
nonsaturable fashion.’</p>
<p class="p">   Steven Connor, <em>Samuel Beckett: Repetition, Theory and Text</em> (1988; Aurora, CO: The Davies Group, 2007), 142.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘I looked at him for only a second; a phrase from the Firbank I had just been reading came back to me: “Très gutter, ma’am”’.</p>
<p class="p">   Alan Hollinghurst, <em>The Swimming-Pool Library</em>, 170.</p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="ExplanColon"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>The Colon of Explanation </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Colons point forward to an explanation or elaboration of what has come before.</p>
<p class="p">   Examples:</p>
<p class="p">   ‘It is just as with living creatures: when soul and body come 
together and remain united, we speak of a living being, but when this 
unity breaks up through the separation of either component, it is clear 
that the living being perishes and no longer exists.’</p>
<p class="p">   Boethius, <em>The Consolation of Philosophy</em> (c. 524; London: Penguin, 1969), 105-6.</p>
<p class="p">   ‘[Pindar’s] complex stanzas were patterned in sets of three: moving 
in a dance rhythm to the left, the chorus chanted the strophe; moving to
 the right, the antistrophe; then, standing still, the epode’</p>
<p class="p">   M.H. Abrams, <em>A Glossary of Literary Terms</em>, 198.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="Exercises"></a><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Punctuation Exercises<br /> </strong> </p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="ClausesEX"></a><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Independent and Dependent Clauses Exercise </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Identify the independent and dependent clauses in the following 
sentences. If there is more than one of either type of clause in a 
sentence, label them i1, i2 etc., or d1, d2 etc.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘Next day the light of the October morning was falling in dusty 
shafts through the uncurtained windows, and the hum of traffic rose from
 the street.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Virginia Woolf, <em>A Room of One’s Own</em> (1929) in <em>A Room of One’s Own/Three Guineas</em>, ed. Michèle Barrett (London: Penguin, 1993), 86.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘When he saw it he drew back, and his cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Oscar Wilde, <em>A Picture of Dorian Gray</em> (1891; London: Penguin, 2000), 27.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘Railway termini gave us weepy farewells and course recouplings.’ </li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Julian Barnes, <em>Metroland </em>(1980; London: Vintage, 2009), 29.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘While Christophine scrubbed my face and tied my plaits with a 
fresh piece of string, she told me that those were the new people at 
Nelson’s Rest.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Jean Rhys, <em>Wide Sargasso Sea </em>(1966; London: Penguin, 1997), 11.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘At a students’ eating-house, they found an American girl who 
seemed to remember Robert; at least, he was called Robert and fitted the
 description.’ </li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Muriel Spark, <em>Territorial Rights</em> (1979; London: Penguin, 1991), 128.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘There is something more, if I could find a name for it.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Robert Louis Stevenson, <em>The Strange Case of Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde</em> (1886; London: Penguin, 2003), 16.<br /> </p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Click here to see answers.  </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <a class="index-element" id="CommaEX"></a><br /> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Comma Exercise </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Can you specify which types of commas (Listing, Joining or Bracketing) are being used in these examples?</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘To write the Life of him who excelled all mankind in writing the
 lives of others, and who, whether we consider his extraordinary 
endowments, or his various works, has been equalled by few in any age, 
is an arduous, and may be reckoned in me a presumptuous task.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   James Boswell, <em>Boswell’s Life of Johnson</em> (1791), ed. George Birkbeck Hill, vol. I (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1934), 25.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘Here you are barricading yourself in your room, giving only yes 
or no for an answer, causing your parents a great deal of unnecessary 
anxiety, and besides – I merely mention this in passing –neglecting your
 duties towards the firm in a positively outrageous manner.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Franz Kafka, ‘Metamorphosis’ (1915) in <em>Metamorphosis and Other Stories</em>, trans. and ed. Malcolm Pasley (London: Penguin, 2000), 83-4.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘It is impossible to escape the impression that people commonly 
use false standards of measurement – that they seek power, success and 
wealth for themselves and admire them in others, and that they 
underestimate what is of true value in life.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Sigmund Freud, ‘Civilization and Its Discontents’ (1930) in <em>The Standard Edition</em>, vol. 21 (London: The Hogarth Press, 1995), 64.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘Romance, which expresses the desire to escape from real life, 
was suffering eclipse, or rather, perhaps, running into new moulds; the 
novel, which represents an acceptance of real life, was being born.’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Arundell Esdaile, <em>A List of English Tales and Prose Romances Printed Before 1740</em> (New York: Burt Franklin, 1971), xxi.</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> ‘The Olivers, who had bought the place something over a century ago, had no connection with the Warings<strong>, </strong>the Elveys, the Mannerings or the Burnets;’</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">   Virginia Woolf, <em>Between the Acts </em>(1941), ed. Gillian Beer (London: Penguin, 1992), 7.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong> Click here to see answers. </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong><a class="index-element" id="SemicolonEX"></a><br /> </strong> <strong> </strong><strong> Semicolon Exercise </strong></p>
<p class="p">   Which of the following sentences includes an incorrect semicolon? In
 each case where you spot one, can you replace it with a correct 
punctuation mark?</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Many of Dickens’s depictions of women are patronising and 
insipid; nevertheless, he is undoubtedly one of the greatest authors who
 ever lived. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> We received few responses to our survey; less than a dozen. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Her husband stood at the top of the stairs; he was wearing the shirt that she had given him. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Full stops are often used to separate independent clauses; 
however, if the two clauses are closely linked, a semicolon can be more 
effective. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Her time in the theatre taught her a valuable lesson; confidence is the key to success. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> While the grown-ups bickered and complained; Vanessa read her fascinating new book. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> It was the best of times; it was the worst of times. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> Emma constantly meddles in other peoples’ business; a habit that gets her into trouble. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> At the laundrette I saw Mary Slater, the shop assistant; Daniel 
Mechin, the investment banker; and Robert Ferrero, the art teacher. </li>
</ul>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/documents/Punctuation_answers" target="_self">Download the punctuation guide to see answers (Word doc)</a> </li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content -->

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/graduate/MThome.htm
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Prospective Students</h1>

<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english">Undergraduate</a></h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english">BA English<br /></a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english/modern-language-plus" target="_self">BA Modern Language Plus (English and a Modern Language)</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/latin-and-english-ba">BA Latin and English</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/greek-and-english-ba">BA Greek and English</a></li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/affiliates" target="_self">Affiliates/Visiting Students</a></h2>






<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/postgraduate">Postgraduate </a></h2>





<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture">MA in English: Issues in
Modern Culture</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-english-linguistics">MA in English Linguistics</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree" target="_self">MA Medieval and Renaissance Studies<br /></a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/early-modern-studies-ma" target="_self">MA Early Modern Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/mphil-eng-lang">MPhil/PhD in English Language
and Literature</a></li>
</ul>
<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/UCL_8Apr2011_0014.jpg" width="1280" height="854" alt="6" class="xl-image" title="6" />

<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Study Abroad and Affiliate Students</h1>
<p class="p">Full details about applying as an Study Abroad/Affiliate student in the English Department can be found on the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/study-abroad-ucl/study-abroad-guide" target="_self">UCL Study Abroad Guide</a>.</p>
<p class="p">Please note that it is <strong>only </strong>possible to take course units in English as a Study Abroad student if you register with the English Department, or if you are joint-registered between English and another department. <br /></p>
<p class="p">Courses in English are <strong>not </strong>available to Year Abroad students who are registered in different departments.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

         

         
              

<footer class="footer wrapper"> 
    <div class="footer__inner clearfix">
        
            <article class="block block--col-1">

<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english" target="_self">BA English</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english/modern-language-plus" target="_self">BA Modern Language Plus (English and a Modern Language)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/latin-and-english-ba" target="_self">BA Latin and English</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/greek-and-english-ba" target="_self">BA Greek and English</a></li>
</ul>


            </article>

<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-english-linguistics" target="_self">MA in English Linguistics</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars/degree" target="_self">MA Medieval and Renaissance Studies</a></li>

            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
