                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">MPhil/PhD in English Literature and Language</h1>


<h3 class="heading"></h3>






<h3 class="heading"></h3>








<h5 class="heading"></h5>


<p class="p">One of the highest-ranking English Departments in the UK, UCL provides fantastic opportunities for PhD students to study in the heart of literary London, with access to vast quantities of resources and research materials, and a high number of academic staff working on a diverse range of specialist topics.</p>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Studying for a PhD at UCL</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">With access to a vast collection of archival materials, and world-leading supervision in a wide range of literary periods and topics, UCL is one of the best universities in which to study for an English PhD.      <br /></p>
<p class="p">There are normally about 45 students undertaking research degrees in the
 department. Graduate students initially register for the MPhil degree, 
but usually in the second year, when a realistic and workable thesis has 
been confirmed, and work-in-progress and a 
future plan have been discussed, students are upgraded from MPhil to PhD
 status.</p>
<p class="p"> Students accepted for admission are given a principal 
supervisor with whom the student will work closely during the course of 
the degree. A secondary supervisor is also appointed to provide 
additional advice. Great importance is attached to matching student and 
supervisor, and ensuring that students' progress is well monitored. 
Students meet either one or other supervisor approximately ten times 
during the academic year. The Department is eager to ensure PhD 
completion rates within four years, and therefore operates end-of-year 
interviews as well as offering students opportunities to provide tutorial teaching.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Duration</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Students are expected to complete the
 PhD within three or four years of registration, and the minimum period of 
registration is two years. Under certain conditions (as set out in the 
UCL <a href="http://www.grad.ucl.ac.uk/">Doctoral School</a> website) research can be undertaken on a part-time basis. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Research Specialisms</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">The
 Department offers MPhil/PhD supervision in a wide range of topics, 
including English and English-related language and literature from Old 
English to the present day. <br /></p>
<p class="p">Some specialisms among members of staff in 
which the Department would particularly welcome applications are: the 
history of the English language; corpus linguistics; 
London in literature; Old and Middle English manuscript 
studies; relations between English and insular and continental French 
writings from the 13th to the 15th centuries; post-medieval bibliography
 and palaeography; history of the book, textual and editorial theory and
 practice in all periods; Shakespeare studies, including Shakespeare’s 
London; the literature of the Elizabethan court; women writers of the 
16th and 17th centuries; classicism in 17th- and 18th-century literary 
culture; literature and science in the 17th and 18th centuries; 
revolutionary writings in the Romantic period; the history and theory of
 consumer culture; homosexuality and literary 
history; literature and technology in late 19th-century and early 
20th-century literature; Victorian and Edwardian writings on sexuality 
and adolescence; 19th- and 20th-century magazine publishing; 20th and 
21st-century modernism and post-modernism; 20th-century poetry, 
especially the New York School.</p>
<p class="p">This is not an exhaustive list, however; and staff would welcome enquiries from any student who wishes to pursue a PhD in an area where the tutor has supervisory expertise. <a href="/silva/english/staff/academic-staff" target="_self"><br /></a></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Read about our staff research interests</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p"> For many of the specialisms listed above, the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/Library/">UCL Library</a> has relevant book and manuscript holdings in its excellent <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/Library/special-coll/index.shtml">Special Collections</a>
 department. Among these are the George Orwell Archive; Little 
Magazines; the Routledge and Kegan Paul Archives (publishing history); 
the Brougham Papers and papers of the Society for the Diffusion of 
Useful Knowledge (19th-century liberalism); the Chadwick Papers 
(19th-century sanitary reform); the Karl Pearson Papers (eugenics). The 
UCL Library also has superb holdings in London history. For language 
topics the Department is especially well placed, as it houses the 
world-renowned Survey of English Usage.</p>
<p class="p"> Other London archives with manuscript and rare book resources relevant to the Department’s research interests include the:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> <a href="http://www.ull.ac.uk/">University of London Research Library Services</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.bl.uk/">British Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/scripts/semaphoreserver.exe?STYPE=AZ&amp;AZ=G&amp;DB=col&amp;B=Len&amp;QUERY01=libraries&amp;PROP01=s=none,t=b,p=I1&amp;ORGANISE_CODED=:F9&amp;TBPT=Libraries&amp;TBSY=Guildhall%20Library&amp;TBDB=col_taxonomy&amp;PROP00=t%3di&amp;QUERY00=&amp;B2_DESC=Libraries&amp;B2=I1libraries">Guildhall Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.londonlibrary.co.uk/">London Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.lse.ac.uk/library/">Library of the London School of Economics</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.english.qmul.ac.uk/drwilliams/index.html">Dr Williams’s Library</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.vam.ac.uk/nal/">Library of the Victoria and Albert Museum</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.royalsoc.ac.uk/page.asp?id=1646">Archives of the Royal Society</a></li>
<li>the <a href="http://www.thewomenslibrary.ac.uk/">Women’s Library at London Metropolitan University</a>, </li>
<li>and many more.</li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Current Students' Research Topics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>


<h3 class="heading">Selected list of current students' research topics </h3>




<ul class="disc">
<li>The Point of View of the Poor- Depictions of Poverty around Orwell, 1925-1935</li>
<li>Radicalising the Novel Form: the Experimental Novel from Beckett to B.S. Johnson</li>
<li>Emily Dickinson and Apophatic Poetics</li>
<li>Self-Doubt: Revision in Coetzee, Roth and Hill</li>
<li>The Whitechapel Boys and the Little Magazine</li>
<li>East Asian Landscapes in Ezra Pound</li>
<li>The Reception of Beowulf in the light of BL. MS Cotton Vitellius A.XV </li>
<li>Entrances to the Underworld in Anglo-Saxon Literature</li>
<li>Nationalism and Scots Poetry in the twentieth century</li>
<li>Reading for a Cure in Edmund Spenser and Robert Burton</li>
<li>Wyndham Lewis and the Market</li>
<li>Gardens, Society and civilising space in the work of Virginia Woolf</li>
<li>Lexical Semantic variation and change: an onomasiological approach</li>
</ul>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">The Research Proposal</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Your research proposal does not need
to be long (typically somewhere between
800-1000 words). The most important things we are looking for you to explain
are:</p>
<p class="p">1) What primary literature/texts will you be studying?</p>
<p class="p">2) What is your idea/approach to this literature?</p>
<p class="p">3) How does your project fit in to the secondary
literature/criticism on this topic?</p>
<p class="p">4) Practical details, like which archives you will use,
roughly how long you will spend on each chapter, what each chapter may be
about, etc</p>
<p class="p">5) That you have considered how the chosen project will
work within a 100-120,000 word limit (so it's clearly not something so small
that it's 20,000 words maximum, nor have you chosen something so big that you
couldn't possibly do it justice in 500,000).</p>
<p class="p">Proposals and intentions often change a little/quite
a lot once they are on the course, but the important thing is just to
demonstrate that you have thought about the practicalities and you have a
clear, viable research topic that we could supervise in the Department, and
which you could complete within three years.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Application Process</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Potential research 
students can apply at any time throughout the year. <strong>If you wish to be considered for AHRC funding, you must submit a completed application (including both references) by 5th January 2018 (as well as completing the LAHP form by 29th January)</strong>.<br /></p>
<p class="p">For entry in 
September 2018 without applying for funding, candidates must have submitted completed applications 
(including references) by 20th July 2018. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The
 Department will make decisions on who to admit for the MPhil/PhD based 
on the strength of the proposed research project, the applicant's grades
 in undergraduate and Masters level study, and the suitability (and 
availability) of academic staff in the Department to supervise the 
proposed project.</p>
<p class="p">Applications must include a research proposal, two references, a CV, and transcripts from your previous academic courses. Further details can be found in the main Graduate Application section of the main UCL website.<br /></p>


<h3 class="heading">Interviews</h3>




<p class="p">Shortlisted 
candidates from the UK will be usually invited to a short interview at 
UCL to discuss their research proposal in more detail: this will 
generally be with the Tutor for Graduates, and the applicant's proposed 
supervisor. Applicants from overseas are generally interviewed via Skype where possible.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Funding</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Scholarships which you may be eligible to apply for are listed here: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/scholarships/graduate/" target="_self">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/scholarships/graduate/</a> <br /></p>


<h3 class="heading">AHRC</h3>




<p class="p"> If you are interested in and are eligible for AHRC funding, you will need to apply via the <strong>London Arts and Humanities Partnerships (LAHP)</strong>
 (a consortium linking UCL, King's and the School of Advanced Studies 
for funding purposes). You can find out some more details about this, 
and a link to the application form, here: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lahp/studentships" target="_self">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lahp/studentships</a>. </p>
<p class="p"> All applicants that wish to be considered for funding need to have submitted a completed LAHP application form to LAHP by <strong>21st January 2018 at the very latest.</strong></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Applicants who are interested in LAHP funding must also have submitted a completed PhD application to UCL by 5th January 2018.</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p"> If you are applying from the UK, and are liable to be shortlisted for 
interview, then candidates should ideally be available for interview 
from December to mid-February.</p>


<h3 class="heading">LAHP FORMS</h3>




<p class="p"> The online LAHP form asks students to name their 
proposed supervisor so they can provide a reference. As many applicants may not yet be sure who their 
supervisor would be, and may not have contacted them in the past, it may be difficult for some students to complete this section. If you wish to submit a LAHP form before you are shortlisted for interview, then you should put down the name of the tutor that you think would be the best academic fit, but it may be better and easier if you do not submit the LAHP form until you are confident that you know who would be supervising your project. We will make shortlisting decisions on all applicants prior to the LAHP deadline of 21st January, so you will certainly still be able to complete the LAHP form on time.</p>
<p class="p">If you have been in discussions with a particular tutor and feel confident that you know who your supervisor would be, then do feel free to submit the LAHP form with their details on. Tutors will then complete the supporting reference after your interview, assuming you are successful.</p>
<p class="p">The LAHP form is not too complex, but does require you to explain your research proosal in 750 words or fewer: if you have written significantly more than that in your UCL application, you will need to think about how to reduce the word count.<br /></p>
<p class="p"> If you have any further questions about this, please email james.phillips@ucl.ac.uk.</p>


<h3 class="heading">Wolfson Scholarships (please check again after January 2018 for information on funding for 2018-19)</h3>




<p class="p">Six Wolfson Postgraduate Scholarships in the Humanities 
are normally available for PhD students in the areas of
 language, history and literature. The 
Wolfson Scholarship, like the AHRC, provides full funding, including 
living expenses, for three years. The Wolfson Scholarship is only available for students from the UK or EU. Typically the English Department will
 secure two of these awards, although this is not guaranteed.<br /></p>
<p class="p">There is no application process for the Wolfson Scholarship- we consider all applications submitted by <strong>5th January</strong> based on the strength of the standard UCL application form and research proposal.</p>
<p class="p">Further information can be obtained from <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/jfigs/wolfson-postgraduate-scholarship" target="_blank">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/jfigs/wolfson-postgraduate-scholarship</a>.<br /></p>


<h3 class="heading">Graduate Research Scholarships </h3>




<p class="p"> UCL Graduate Research Scholarships aim to attract 
high-quality students to undertake research at UCL. Up to 20 UCL 
Graduate Research Scholarships (GRS) are available to prospective and 
current research students from any country (awards to overseas students 
are called Overseas Research Scholarships (ORS), and reduce the overseas fee 
rate to the level of the Home/EU rate). It is possible to receive both an ORS and a GRS.<br /></p>
<p class="p"> More details about the application process for the Graduate Research
Scholarships, including deadlines, can be found here: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/graduate/UK-EU_Res/grs">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/scholarships/graduate/UK-EU_Res/grs</a></p>
<p class="p">Applicants should send their 'lay summary' by <strong>Friday,</strong> <strong>5th January, 2018</strong>. <br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Please note that there is no need to provide an additional reference at this stage: just the lay summary. There is also no application form. If you are longlisted for the scholarship, then we will complete a supervisor support reference for you in time for our internal deadlines. </strong><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Research Skills</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Students work closely with their supervisors, and also participate in the research seminars run by the Department, the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/GradSchool/">Doctoral School</a>, and the <a href="http://ies.sas.ac.uk/">Institute of English Studies</a>
 at the University of London. Research is expected to take students into
 numerous libraries, archives and databases, not only within London, but
 also throughout Britain, and indeed further afield. When completed and 
submitted, the thesis is defended in an oral examination.</p>
<p class="p"> The Department places great emphasis on the need to provide
 opportunities for students to discuss their work and to learn new 
research methods. New research students attend a weekly seminar on 
essential skills, ranging from the use of libraries and bibliographies 
to new database and computing skills. Further introductory research 
seminars are run by the UCL <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/GradSchool/">Doctoral School</a>, and by the University of London's <a href="http://ies.sas.ac.uk/">Institute of English Studies</a>.</p>
<p class="p"> In addition, several other seminars, informal as well as 
formal, are held within the Department. The main formal seminar series 
is organised by the Graduate Tutor and the President of the Graduate 
Society and invites speakers from within and outside the Department to 
present papers on a wide variety of topics. Other seminar series and 
discussion groups are run by graduates, and include opportunities to try
 out early versions of work-in-progress.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Teaching and Employment Prospects</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>


<h3 class="heading">Teaching opportunities for research students</h3>




<p class="p"> The Department also hopes to offer many graduates the 
opportunity of doing a limited amount of teaching, either of seminars or
 tutorials or both, normally in the students' second year of research.</p>
<p class="p"> Graduate students organise a one-day conference each year; many of the papers delivered at the conference are published in <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/graduate/MThome.htm">Movable Type</a>, the Department's graduate-led online journal.</p>
<p class="p"> Graduate students have organised highly successful summer 
workshops for Year 12 school students, supported by funding from UCL and
 the University of London. </p>


<h3 class="heading">Employment Prospects</h3>




<p class="p">




Graduate students from the Department have an excellent 
record of securing full-time posts in British institutions of higher 
education. In recent years successful doctoral students have gone on to 
academic positions here in UCL, as well as Oxford, Cambridge, the 
wider University of London, and in the United States, Canada, and New Zealand.<br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Further Information</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">For further information, please email the Admissions and Postgraduate Administrator, Clare Stainthorp: <a href="mailto:c.stainthorp@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">c.stainthorp@ucl.ac.uk </a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Apply Online</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> You can find a link to the online application form on the main UCL website at the bottom of this page: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/apply" target="_self">http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/apply</a> <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>


<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/UCL-2Nov2016_028.jpg" width="1280" height="854" alt="top" class="xl-image" title="top" />

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

            <img src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/images/close.png" alt="X" />Close</a>
        <div id="top" class="masthead">

			<div class="wrapper clearfix">

				<div class="masthead__search">
					<form action="//search2.ucl.ac.uk/s/search.html" method="get">
						<div class="search-form">
							<input type="search" placeholder="Search UCL websites, degrees, short courses, people and more" class="search-form__input search-form__input--search" name="query" value="">

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Postgraduate</h1>
<p class="p">The following postgraduate programmes are currently offered: <br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture" target="_self">MA in English: Issues in Modern Culture</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-english-linguistics" target="_self">MA in English Linguistics</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/mphil-eng-lang" target="_self">MPhil/PhD in English Literature/Language</a></li>
<li><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/mars" target="_self">MA Medieval and Renaissance Studies</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/eme/study/early-modern-studies-ma" target="_self">MA Early Modern Studies</a></li>
</ul>
<p class="p">As a postgraduate in English at UCL you can expect to enjoy:<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>Specialists in every period of English and American literature.</li>
<li>A full programme of research seminars, invited speakers and papers 
given by graduate students themselves, regular classes in research 
methods and career development workshops.</li>
<li>The opportunity to undertake a limited amount of tutorial teaching, normally in the second year of research.</li>
<li>Automatic access to an incomparable range of archives and libraries,
 including the Senate House Library of the University of London and the 
British Library, both of which are nearby.</li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

              <h2 class="as-h5">Undergraduate degrees</h2>

<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ba-english/modern-language-plus" target="_self">BA Modern Language Plus (English and a Modern Language)</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/latin-and-english-ba" target="_self">BA Latin and English</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/greek-and-english-ba" target="_self">BA Greek and English</a></li>
</ul>


            </article>

</ul>

                                  <div class="info">
                                    <h2 class="heading">The resource cannot be found</h2>
                                    <p class="p">
                                      <acronym title="Uniform Resource Locator">URL</acronym>:
                                      http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective/MA_EnglishLinguistics
                                      <br /><br />
                                    </p>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      Most likely causes:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>There might be a typing error in the address.</li>
                                          <li>If you clicked on a link, it may be out of date.</li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      What you can try:
                                    </h4>
                                      <ul>
                                          <li>Retype the address.</li>
                                          <li>Use the search box above to find what you're looking for.</li>
                                          <li>Go to <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk" title="UCL Website">www.ucl.ac.uk</a> and look for the information you want.</li>
                                          <li><a href="javascript:history.back()" title="Back to previous page">Go back to the previous page.</a></li>
                                      </ul>
                                    <h4 class="heading">
                                      More information:
                                    </h4>
                                    <p class="p">
                                        This error (<acronym title="Hypertext Transfer Protocol">HTTP</acronym> 404 Not Found) means that you have connected to the UCL Website, but the page you wanted was not found. It's possible that the webpage is temporarily unavailable. Alternatively, the UCL Website might have changed or removed the webpage. 
                                    </p>
                                  </div>
                                

                                <!-- end main slot where silva content gets rendered--> 
                                <!--End center content area-->
                            </div>
                            <div id="ie_clearing">&nbsp;</div>

                        </div>

        <h1><span>English Pronunciation: a Contemporary Approach</span></h1>
        <!--noindex-->
            <ul class="tags">
      	               <li>
			    <span href="#" class="tags__item tags__item--method">
					<span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-hours">
                                </span>

                            </span>

 <section class="block block--full-width feature--grey--lighten">
     <article class="layout__content">
         
    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-costs">
              <h1 class="price">Cost: <span>&pound;450</span>
                                       
                      </h1>
             
    </article>

    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-dates">
        
    
        <h2>Availability</h2>
        <ul class="sidebar__item__list course-dates__list">
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                                <span class="apply">Download an application form on the PaLS website for:</span>
                                <br />
                            
                            <time datetime="2017/12/18">18 December 2017</time>
                        </div>
                        <a data-trackevent="LifeLearning-ApplyClicked"
                           class="trackevent"
                           href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/pals/study/cpd/cpd-courses/executive-programme/executive-Eng-Pron">
                            <span class="pill pill--button">Book now</span>
                        </a>
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                                <span class="no-apply">Booking will open soon for:</span>
                                <br />
                            
                            <time datetime="2018/03/26">26 March 2018</time>
                        </div>
                        
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                            <time datetime="2018/06/12">12 June 2018</time>
                        </div>
                        
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                            <time datetime="2018/06/18">18 June 2018</time>
                        </div>
                        
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
        </ul>
        
    

    </article>


         

<h2 class="heading">Overview</h2>





<p class="p">                             This four-day course will be useful if <strong>you use English in a professional context</strong> and want to <strong>improve your pronunciation</strong>.</p>
<p class="p">The aims of the course are to:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>give you structured<strong> practical feedback on your 
pronunciation</strong> (within the group setting), so that you have a <strong>programme 
for continuing practice</strong> after the course</li>
<li><strong>outline
 the contemporary English sound system</strong> (vowels, consonants, stress and 
intonation) - the focus will be on Standard British, with reference to 
General American</li>
</ul>
<p class="annotation">This course is run by UCL's Division of Psychology and Language Sciences (PaLS).</p>

<h2 class="heading">Course content</h2>





<p class="p">During the course you'll:<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>learn about new developments in English - with discussion of both the phonetic and socio-cultural factors which have shaped contemporary English language</li>
<li>explore informational packaging in English, which can enhance effective communication, teaching and presentation giving</li>
<li>participate interactively with other students, giving you the opportunity to improve your language skills and confidence</li>
<li>get ideas and resources for English pronunciation teaching, if applicable to your work, including use of the internet</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">You'll be encouraged to take part in methodological debate and discussion.</p>

<h2 class="heading">What makes this course special?</h2>





<p class="p">A large component of the course is about <strong>individualised feedback and practice recommendations </strong>- this means you'll be able to address the pronunciation issues that affect you personally. <br /></p>
<p class="p">You'll have access to the tutor's five SMART techniques for psycho-motor practice.</p>
<p class="p">You'll work on contemporary speech and learn how this differs from conservative descriptions. <br /></p>
<p class="p">You'll also have:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>networking opportunities</li>
<li>the benefit of spending several days in a native-speaking environment</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">You'll leave the course with greater awareness, confidence and control in using English for professional purposes.</p>

<h2 class="heading">Structure and certification</h2>





<p class="p">The course will be structured to include the following:<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>ear training on English contrasts with critical reference to phonetic symbols</li>
<li>analysis of recordings and videos of native speech</li>
<li>extensive use of five SMART speech practice techniques</li>
<li>extensive feedback by the tutor on your spontaneous and read speech</li>
<li>construction of individual prioritised recommendations for your future practice</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">There will be an optional cultural day on 22 December, to help those applying through the Erasmus scheme to explore London.</p>
<p class="p">At the end of the course you'll get a Certificate of Attendance.</p>

<h2 class="heading">Who this course is for</h2>





<p class="p">The course will be beneficial to anyone who uses English in their workplace and wants to improve their pronunciation, including:<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> academics</li>
<li>teacher trainers </li>
<li>educators at all levels (pre-school, primary, secondary, vocational, adult) </li>
<li>non-teaching staff such as administrators, career advisors and counsellors</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Eligibility</h2>





<p class="p">No technical knowledge of phonetics is required, as all concepts and symbols will be explained as part of the course. </p>

<h2 class="heading">Learning outcomes</h2>





<p class="p">This course will enable you to:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>identify and produce key English contrasts, especially those not made in your native language</li>
<li>identify and produce English word-linking patterns</li>
<li>execute five key SMART techniques for speech practice</li>
<li>analyse discourse according to informational content and produce it with appropriate English intonation</li>
<li>set goals for future speech practice and integrate speech changes into regular English use</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Find out more</h2>





<p class="p">Read an <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/case-studies/phonetics-pronunciation-geoff-lyndsey" target="_self">interview with Dr Geoff Lindsey</a>, the course tutor.<br /></p>
<p class="lead"> <strong>Sign up for short course announcements</strong>: Subscribe to the <a href="http://eepurl.com/cL1kx5" target="_self">UCL Life Learning newsletter</a> to receive news and updates on courses in your chosen area. (For updates on a specific course, contact the administrator - see 'Contact information'.)</p>




         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        


    <div class="course-teacher box--alt tagged">

                  <div class="tag">Course team</div>



                    

                      

                  <div class="media">

                      <a href="#">

                      <img alt="" class="media__aside"
                           src="/silva/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg">
                      </a>

                    <div class="media__body">
                      <h2>Dr Geoff Lindsey</h2>
                      <p>Geoff is an Honorary Lecturer in Linguistics at UCL and Director of UCL’s annual Summer Course in English Phonetics. He holds a first class Bachelor’s degree from UCL and a PhD from the University of California, Los Angeles. He's taught at London (UCL and City), Edinburgh and Cambridge Universities. His publications include research on American and British dialects. He was a contributor to the Kiel revision of the International Phonetic Alphabet, and a consultant phonetician for the Concise Oxford Dictionary on CD-ROM.</p>
                    </div>

                  </div>

                      <br />

                    
                  
                    

                      
                  
                    

                      
                  
                    

                      
                  
                    

                      
                  
                    

                      
                  


              </div>

              </a>-->

                    <h2></h2>

                    <p>
                        “Thorough coverage of theory and practical aspects!” (June 2016)<br/><br/>“Excellent! Geoff is a gifted and dedicated teacher.                     </p>

              </div>

 <div class="layout__sidebar">

    
    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-costs">
              <h1 class="price">Cost: <span>&pound;450</span>
                                       
                      </h1>
             
    </article>

    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-dates">
        
    
        <h2>Availability</h2>
        <ul class="sidebar__item__list course-dates__list">

                <div id="manual_relatedsearch">

                    <h1 class="related__header">Related</h1>
                    <ul class="related__list">
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">
                            
                                <a href="#"><img alt=""
    class="related__list__thumb media__aside"
    src="/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg"></a>
                                <div class="media__body">
                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/summer-course-english-phonetics">
                                    Summer Course in English Phonetics</a></h2>
                                    <p>Spend two weeks in London this summer studying a short course in English Phonetics at UCL. For English teachers or students.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>
                       
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">
                            
                                <a href="#"><img alt=""
    class="related__list__thumb media__aside"
    src="/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg"></a>
                                <div class="media__body">
                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/presentation-skills-in-english-non-native-english-speakers">
                                    Presentation Skills in English for Non-Native English Speakers</a></h2>
                                    <p>A two-day interactive workshop to help non-native speakers of English deliver more effective and professional presentations. Learn to make a greater impact, build rapport and better influence an English speaking audience.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>
                       
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">
                            
                                <a href="#"><img alt=""
    class="related__list__thumb media__aside"
    src="/lifelearning/images/english-usge-survey-logo-sq.jpg"></a>
                                <div class="media__body">
                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/english-corpus-linguistics-summer-school">
                                    English Corpus Linguistics Summer School</a></h2>
                                    <p>A three-day introduction to corpus linguistics for students of language and linguistics and teachers of English. Gain a knowledge of the basic concepts and methodologies used in English corpus linguistics.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>
                       
                    </ul>
                </div>
           </article>

                </li>
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
              
                
              
            </ul>
    </nav>

 <div id="main" class="clearfix">
      <!-- Start Silva content --> 

	

 <!-- Modernizr script -->
<link rel="shortcut icon" src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/silva/UCLLifeLearning/js/modernizr-custom.js" />
<script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/silva/UCLIndigoSkin/js/lib/underscore-1.6.0.min.js"></script>

 <div class="hero">
      <div class="hero__body">

        <h1><span>Media Skills for Non-Native English Speakers: Handling the Media - TV, Radio, Print</span></h1>
        <!--noindex-->
            <ul class="tags">
      	               <li>
			    <span href="#" class="tags__item tags__item--method">
					<span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-hours">
                                </span>
                                   9-10 hours
                            </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <span href="#"
    class="tags__item tags__item--method">
                                <span aria-hidden="true"
    class="icon icon-duration">
                                </span>
                                2 days 
                            </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <span href="#" class="tags__item tags__item--industry">
                                <span aria-hidden="true"
    class="icon icon-hours"> Next start date:
                                </span>
                                13 April 2018
                            </span>
                        </li>
         </ul>
        <!--endnoindex-->
      </div>
  </div>

 <section class="block block--full-width feature--grey--lighten">
     <article class="layout__content">
         
    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-costs">
              <h1 class="price">Cost: <span>&pound;550</span>
                                       
                      </h1>
             
    </article>

    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-dates">
        
    
        <h2>Availability</h2>
        <ul class="sidebar__item__list course-dates__list">
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                                <span class="no-apply">Booking will open soon for:</span>
                                <br />
                            
                            <time datetime="2018/04/13">13 April 2018</time>
                        </div>
                        
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
        </ul>
        
    

    </article>


         

<h2 class="heading">Overview</h2>





<p class="p">                 This intensive two-day workshop will help non-native speakers of English <strong>handle print, radio and television interviews in English more effectively</strong>. </p>
<p class="p">You'll <strong>learn how to deliver messages more clearly and confidently</strong>, and stay ‘on message’ under pressure.</p>
<p class="annotation"> This course is run by UCL's Division of Psychology and Language Sciences (PaLS).</p>

<h2 class="heading">Course content</h2>





<p class="p">This course will help you:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>develop your skills in handling the media</li>
<li>design and/or strengthen your 'key messages'</li>
<li>deliver these messages in a more effective and influential way to an English-speaking audience</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">You'll learn some tips and techniques and participate in ‘real time’ recorded interviews in each medium. </p>
<p class="p">You'll receive individual coaching<strong> </strong>and constructive feedback throughout.</p>

<h2 class="heading">Learning outcomes</h2>





<p class="p"> This workshop will help you to:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>understand the requirements of journalists</li>
<li>handle interviews more effectively</li>
<li>deliver your messages more effectively</li>
<li>articulate more clearly</li>
<li>stay 'on message' under pressure</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Certification</h2>





<p class="p">You'll receive a certificate of attendance when you complete the course.</p>
<p class="lead"> <strong>Sign up for short course announcements</strong>: Subscribe to the <a href="http://eepurl.com/cL1kx5" target="_self">UCL Life Learning newsletter</a> to receive news and updates on courses in your chosen area. (For updates on a specific course, contact the administrator - see 'Contact information'.)</p>




         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        


    <div class="course-teacher box--alt tagged">

                  <div class="tag">Course team</div>



                    

                      

                  <div class="media">

                      <a href="#">

                      <img alt="" class="media__aside"
                           src="/silva/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg">
                      </a>

                    <div class="media__body">
                      <h2>Josette Lesser</h2>
                      <p>Josette has been a media, presentation and leadership communication skills coach and lecturer for over 16 years. In 2007 she formed her own training company, The Communication Experts. She works both nationally and internationally, with clients from both the public and private sectors. She's also a successful print and broadcast journalist, and an accredited PR practitioner.</p>
                    </div>

                  </div>

                      <br />

                    
                  
                    

                      
                  


              </div>



    


    


    








      

        <p class="last-modified mod">
            Course information last modified: 17 Oct 2017, 14:18
        </p>

</article>

 <!-- Modernizr script -->
<link rel="shortcut icon" src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/silva/UCLLifeLearning/js/modernizr-custom.js" />
<script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/silva/UCLIndigoSkin/js/lib/underscore-1.6.0.min.js"></script>

 <div class="hero">
      <div class="hero__body">

        <h1><span>Presentation Skills in English for Non-Native English Speakers</span></h1>
        <!--noindex-->
            <ul class="tags">
      	               <li>
			    <span href="#" class="tags__item tags__item--method">
					<span aria-hidden="true" class="icon icon-hours">
                                </span>
                                   9-10 hours
                            </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <span href="#"
    class="tags__item tags__item--method">
                                <span aria-hidden="true"
    class="icon icon-duration">
                                </span>
                                2 days
                            </span>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <span href="#" class="tags__item tags__item--industry">
                                <span aria-hidden="true"
    class="icon icon-hours"> Next start date:
                                </span>
                                16 February 2018
                            </span>
                        </li>
         </ul>
        <!--endnoindex-->
      </div>
  </div>

 <section class="block block--full-width feature--grey--lighten">
     <article class="layout__content">
         
    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-costs">
              <h1 class="price">Cost: <span>&pound;500</span>
                                       
                      </h1>
             
    </article>

    <article class="sidebar__item box--alt box--alt--small box--alt--rounded course-dates">
        
    
        <h2>Availability</h2>
        <ul class="sidebar__item__list course-dates__list">
            
                <li class="course-dates__list__item course-dates__list__item__new">
                    
                        <div class="booking-col-left">
                            
                                <span class="apply">Download an application form on the PaLS website for:</span>
                                <br />
                            
                            <time datetime="2018/02/16">16 February 2018</time>
                        </div>
                        <a data-trackevent="LifeLearning-ApplyClicked"
                           class="trackevent"
                           href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/pals/study/cpd/cpd-courses/executive-programme/executive-presentation-skills">
                            <span class="pill pill--button">Book now</span>
                        </a>
                    
                    
                    
                    
                </li>
            
        </ul>
        
    

    </article>


         

<h2 class="heading">Overview</h2>





<p class="p">                          This intensive, interactive two-day workshop will help <strong>non-native speakers</strong> of English:<br /></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li> deliver a more effective, professional presentation</li>
<li>make a greater impact, build rapport and better influence an English speaking audience</li>
</ul>
<p class="annotation"> This course is run by UCL's Division of Psychology and Language Sciences (PaLS).</p>

<h2 class="heading">Course content</h2>





<p class="p"> This workshop will help you <strong>improve and develop your presentation skills</strong>, strengthen your key messages, and deliver these in a more effective and influential way.</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Working step-by-step through a presentation </strong>(see ‘pre-course preparation’) you'll deliver your enhanced presentation on day two.<br /></p>
<p class="p"> You'll receive <strong>tips, techniques, individual coaching and constructive feedback </strong>throughout the course.</p>

<h2 class="heading">Learning outcomes</h2>





<p class="p"> This course will help you to:</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>better influence English-speaking audiences</li>
<li>deliver your messages with more clarity</li>
<li>use more effective language</li>
<li>improve your English pronunciation</li>
<li>make a greater impact in English</li>
</ul>

<h2 class="heading">Certification</h2>





<p class="p">You'll receive a certificate of attendance when you complete the course.</p>

<h2 class="heading">Pre-course preparation</h2>





<p class="p"> For practice purposes, you'll be expected to bring along:
</p>
<ul class="disc">
<li>a five-minute introductory presentation</li>
<li>a ten-minute work-related presentation or a subject 
that you have to/will have to speak on, which you've designed. You'll work on this presentation during the course</li>
</ul>
<p class="p">Please make sure your work-related presentation doesn't exceed ten minutes.<br /></p>
<p class="lead"> <strong>Sign up for short course announcements</strong>: Subscribe to the <a href="http://eepurl.com/cL1kx5" target="_self">UCL Life Learning newsletter</a> to receive news and updates on courses in your chosen area. (For updates on a specific course, contact the administrator - see 'Contact information'.)</p>




         
             
        
         
             
        
         
             
        


    <div class="course-teacher box--alt tagged">

                  <div class="tag">Course team</div>



                    

                      

                  <div class="media">

                      <a href="#">

                      <img alt="" class="media__aside"
                           src="/silva/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg">
                      </a>

                    <div class="media__body">
                      <h2>Josette Lesser</h2>
                      <p>Josette has been a media, presentation, and leadership communication skills coach and lecturer for over 16 years. In 2007 she formed her own training company, The Communication Experts. She works both nationally and internationally, with clients from both the public and private sectors. She's also a successful print and broadcast journalist, and an accredited PR practitioner.</p>
                    </div>

                  </div>

                      <br />

                    
                  
                    

                      
                  


              </div>



    


    


    








      

        <p class="last-modified mod">
            Course information last modified: 17 Oct 2017, 13:59
        </p>

</article>

                    <h1 class="related__header">Related</h1>
                    <ul class="related__list">
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">

    class="related__list__thumb media__aside"
    src="/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg"></a>
                                <div class="media__body">
                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/media-skills-non-native-english-speakers-tv-print-radio">
                                    Media Skills for Non-Native English Speakers: Handling the Media - TV, Radio, Print</a></h2>
                                    <p>This two-day course helps non-native English speakers to understand the skills needed by print, radio and television journalists. You'll take part in recorded interviews in each medium and receive individual coaching throughout.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>
                       
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">
                            
                                <a href="#"><img alt=""
    class="related__list__thumb media__aside"
    src="/lifelearning/images/CPD_Logo.jpg"></a>
                                <div class="media__body">
                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/contemporary-english-pronunciation-practical-workshop">
                                    English Pronunciation: a Contemporary Approach</a></h2>
                                    <p>A practical four-day course for those who use English in their professional workplace and want to improve their pronunciation. Includes individual feedback and practice recommendations.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>
                       
                      
                        <li class="related__list__item media">

                                     <h2><a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lifelearning/courses/summer-course-english-phonetics">
                                    Summer Course in English Phonetics</a></h2>
                                    <p>Spend two weeks in London this summer studying a short course in English Phonetics at UCL. For English teachers or students.</p>
                                </div>
                            
                        </li>

                            <div
    class="hero block--full-width"
    style="background-image: url('//www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/images/hero/taught/events/top')">
                                <div class="hero__content">
                                    <div class="hero__body hero__body--background">
                                        <!-- Start special PS intro --> 

    

    
        
                                    
            <h1 class="as-h5">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/taught">Taught</a>
            </h1>
            <h1 class="hero__title">English: Issues in Modern Culture MA</h1>
            
                <ul class="tags hero__tags">
                    <li>
                        <div class="tags__item tag--taught">
                            Subject area:
                            <a
    href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/taught/subject-areas/english"
    class="clicktracker subjecttaught">English</a>
                        </div>
                    </li>
                    <li>
                        <div class="tags__item tag--taught">
                            Faculty:
                            <a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ah"
    class="clicktracker facultytaught">
                                Arts and Humanities <span class="tags__icon icon--after icon--push-left icon-link-ext"></span>
                            </a>
                        </div>
                    </li>
                </ul>
            
        
    

    


<!-- End special PS intro --> 

                                    </div>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                        
                        
                    </header>
                
            

            <div id="main" class="clearfix">
                
                    
                    
                        <ul class="nav nav--inline nav--pull mobile-hide">
                            <li class="nav--inline__li nav__li--prev">
                                <span class="icon icon-left-open"></span>
                                <a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/taught">Taught degrees</a>
                            </li>
                            <li class="nav--inline__li nav--inline__li--icon">
                                <a href="#application" data-scroll="">Application and next steps</a>
                                <span class="icon--after icon-down-open"></span>
                            </li>
                        </ul>
                        <section class="block block--full-width block--highlight">
                            <article class="layout__content copy">
                                <!-- Start Silva content --> 

    
        

            

            
                
        
      <!-- tal:standfirst -->
  <p class="copy__intro">This MA programme introduces students to major works of 19th and 20th-century British, French and American writers and provides a context for those works in philosophical and technological developments of the period. The programme explores a wide range of genres and authors and encourages the development of independent research skills.</p>  <!-- /tal:standfirst -->

  <!-- tal:keyinfo -->
  <section class="copy__section copy__section--key__information copy__section--taught">
    <div class="island island--highlight island--subtle-highlight">
      <h2 class="copy__heading">Key information</h2>
      <div class="clearfix">

                
        <div class="clearfix">
          <h4>Programme starts</h4>
          <p>September 2018</p>
        </div>

        <div class="copy__column dl1-dl2">
          <h4>Modes and duration</h4>
                        <div>
                <strong>Full time:</strong> 1 year              </div>
                                  <div>
                <strong>Part time:</strong> 2 years              </div>
                                                                      </div>

        <div class="copy__column dl3">
          <h4>Tuition fees (2018/19)</h4>

          <dl class="list--defined">
            <dt>UK/EU:</dt>
            <dd>
                              <span>&#163;10,140 (FT)</span>
                                            <span>&#163;5,120 (PT)</span>
                          </dd>

            <dt>Overseas:</dt>
            <dd>
                              <span>&#163;21,160 (FT)</span>
                                            <span>&#163;10,740 (PT)</span>
                          </dd>
          </dl>
        </div>

                                          <div class="copy__column dl4-dl5">
            <h4>Application dates</h4>
                                          <div>
                  <div><strong>All applicants</strong></div>
                                      <div>Open: 16 October 2017</div>
                                                        <div>Close: 27 July 2018</div>
                                  </div>
                                                                                                                </div>
              </div>
                  <div>
            <p>
              <b>Note on fees:</b>
                              The tuition fees shown are for the year indicated above. Fees for subsequent years may increase or otherwise vary. Further information on fee status, fee increases and the fee schedule can be viewed on the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/fees">UCL Current Students website</a>.                                        </p>
          </div>
        
                
                  <div>
                                      <div>
                <strong>Location:</strong> London, Bloomsbury              </div>
                      </div>
        
        <hr>

        <div class="copy__column dc1-dc2">
           <!-- CHECK FOR teaching-training IN SITE? - see isTeacherTraining -->
            <h4>Entry requirements</h4>
            <p>A minimum of an upper second-class Bachelor's degree in a relevant discipline from a UK university or an overseas qualification of an equivalent standard will normally be required. This is a competitive MA, however, and the majority of our successful applicants either have, or are predicted to gain, a first class undergraduate degree (or overseas equivalent).</p>
                    
          <h4>English language requirements</h4>
          <p >If your education has not been conducted in the English language, you will be expected to demonstrate evidence of an adequate level of English proficiency.</p>          <p>The English language level for this programme is: <strong >Good</strong></p>
          <p >Further information can be found on our <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/life/international/english-requirements">English language requirements</a> page.</p>        </div>

        <div class="copy__column dc3-dc4">
          <h4>International students</h4>
          <p >Country-specific information, including details of when UCL representatives are visiting your part of the world, can be obtained from the <a class="clicktracker international" href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/international">International Students website</a>.</p>
          <!-- tal:visa -->
                    <!-- /tal:visa -->

          <p>International applicants can find out the equivalent qualification for their country by selecting from the list below.</p>
