                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Greek and English BA</h1>
<table class="silvatable plain" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<col width="33%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<div class="medium-image   image-left"><img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/greek-and-english-ba" width="192" height="288" alt="Greek and English BA" class="medium-image   image-left" title="Greek and English BA" /></div>


<h4 class="heading">See also the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/degrees/greek-english-ba/" target="_self">UCL Prospectus</a> and the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/classics/study/undergraduate" target="_self">Department of Greek and Latin</a> for further information.</h4>



<p class="p"><br />This three-year degree programme offers students the
opportunity to study Greek and English in parallel, and to gain knowledge of
two diverse bodies of language, literature and culture, and the relations
between them. The programme allows you to develop your skills in criticism and
expression, cultural self-awareness and comparison. The degree is administered
by the Department of Greek and Latin, with teaching shared equally between
Greek and Latin and the English Department.</p>



<h4 class="heading"></h4>






<h4 class="heading"></h4>



<p class="p"><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Degree Structure</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p">Each year you
will take 4.0 course credits, divided evenly between Greek and English.</p>
<p class="p">You must take 1.0
credit in Ancient Greek at a level appropriate to your previous experience
every year. In addition there are compulsory courses including: Interpreting
Greek Literature, Narrative Texts, Intellectual and Cultural Sources in year
one, Classics and Literary Theory in year two, and an interdisciplinary
extended essay in year three.</p>
<p class="p">Remaining
optional courses may be selected from the range offered by UCL Greek &amp;
Latin and UCL English. Students on this degree programme may not take elective
courses in other departments.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year One</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />1.0 credit in Ancient Greek at a level appropriate to your experience
<br />
Interpreting Greek Literature

<br />0.5 credits from Greek and Latin courses at the appropriate level, either in
the original or in translation
<br /> <span class="underline">English Department courses:</span> <br /><a href="/silva/english/current-students/undergraduate/narrative-texts">Narrative Texts

</a><br /><a href="/silva/english/current-students/undergraduate/intellectual-cultural-sources">Intellectual and Cultural Sources</a></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year Two</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />1.0 credit in Ancient Greek at a level appropriate to your previous experience

Classics and Literary Theory

<br />0.5 credits from all Greek and Latin courses, either in the original or in
translation
 <span class="underline">English Department courses:</span> <br /> You will select two 1.0 credit courses from the wide range of second- and
third-year courses available in UCL English (excluding Critical Commentary and
Analysis), listed here: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate">https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate</a>. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year Three</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />1.0 credit in Ancient Greek at a level appropriate to your previous experience

<br />Greek  and English extended essay

<br />Further courses from Greek and Latin, either in the original or in translation
 <br /><span class="underline">English Department courses:</span> <br />You will select two 1.0 credit courses from the wide range of second- and
third-year courses available in UCL English (excluding Critical Commentary and
Analysis), listed here: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate">https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate</a>.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Learning</strong></p>
<p class="p">You will be
taught through lectures, seminars and small-group work. Some courses will
involve student presentations. You will be assigned a Personal Tutor in both
departments, with whom you will review your progress on a regular basis. </p>
<p class="p">In the English
Department students will be producing two tutorial essays a term (one for each
of their English courses) for one-to-one tutorials with their Personal Tutor. A
mark based on tutorial essays and on oral performance in tutorials will be
awarded at the end of each term. These marks do not contribute to
combined-studies students' final degree profiles, but completion of the
tutorial essays is required for the successful completion of the
English component of the course. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong></p>
<p class="p">The course will
be examined by a mixture of essays, end-of-year examinations, and a compulsory
final-year extended essay based on supervised independent research (overseen by
the Greek and Latin Department). Some Greek-language courses involve in-class
tests and grammar quizzes. 
 

The English component consists of six written papers, two per year. All courses
will be examined by written examination at the end of the year in which they
are taught. Students may choose to write one Course Essay of not more than
8,000 words long in place of one three-hour desk examination, either in their
second or third year. (Please note that as the Literary Linguistics and
Literary Representation and History of Homosexuality courses are both examined
by Course Essay, only one of these courses can be chosen as part of the Greek
and English BA.)</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Information For Schools</h1>
<p class="p">If you are an English teacher in a school or sixth form college, or are involved in outreach or access to university at your institution and would be interested in holding some kind of event with UCL for your students, be it in your school or on the UCL campus, please contact the Admissions Officer, James Phillips (james.phillips@ucl.ac.uk) who would be very happy to discuss possible options with you.</p>
<p class="p">Please note that due to time and budgetary constraints, it is unlikely that we will be able to arrange any school-based events outside London and the South East. In these cases, you may find it best to contact the university's dedicated outreach office.</p>
<p class="p">Further information about the kinds of outreach and access to university work which UCL carry out can be found on the website of the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/widening-participation/wp-home" target="_self">UCL Widening Participation Team.</a></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Latin and English BA</h1>
<table class="silvatable plain" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="50%" class="align-left" />
<col width="50%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
<td class="align-left">
  &nbsp;
</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>

<h2 class="heading"></h2>





<div class="medium-image   image-left"><img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/latin-and-english-ba" width="166" height="249" alt="Latin and English BA" class="medium-image   image-left" title="Latin and English BA" /></div>

<h3 class="heading"> </h3>







<h4 class="heading"></h4>




<h2 class="heading"></h2>







<h3 class="heading"></h3>







<h4 class="heading">See also the<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/degrees/latin-english-ba/" target="_self"> </a><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/degrees/latin-english-ba/" target="_self">UCL Prospectus</a> and <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/classics/study/undergraduate" target="_self">Department of Greek and Latin</a> the  for further information.</h4>



<p class="p">This three-year degree programme offers students the
opportunity to study Latin and English in parallel, and to gain knowledge of
two diverse bodies of language, literature and culture, and the relations
between them. The programme allows students to develop their skills in
criticism and expression, cultural self-awareness and comparison. The degree is
administered by the Department of Greek and Latin, with teaching shared equally
between Greek and Latin and the English Department.<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong><br /></strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Degree
Structure</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p">Each year you
will take 4.0 course credits, divided evenly between Latin and English.</p>
<p class="p">You must take 1.0
credit in Latin at a level appropriate to your previous experience every year.
In addition there are compulsory courses including: Interpreting Latin
Literature, Narrative Texts, Intellectual and Cultural Sources in year one,
Classics and Literary Theory in year two, and an interdisciplinary extended
essay in year three.</p>
<p class="p">Remaining optional
courses may be selected from the range offered by UCL Greek &amp; Latin and UCL
English. Students on this degree programme may not take elective courses in
other departments.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year One</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />
1.0 credit in Latin at a level appropriate to your experience
<br />
Interpreting Latin Literature

<br />0.5 credits from Greek and Latin courses at the appropriate level, either in
the original or in translation
<br /> <span class="underline">English Department courses:
 </span><br /><a href="/silva/english/current-students/undergraduate/narrative-texts">Narrative Texts
</a><br /> <a href="/silva/english/current-students/undergraduate/intellectual-cultural-sources">Intellectual and Cultural Sources</a></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year Two</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />
1.0 credit in Latin at a level appropriate to your previous experience
<br />
Classics and Literary Theory

<br />0.5 credits from all Greek and Latin courses, either in the original or in
translation<br /><span class="underline">English Department courses:</span> <br />You will select two 1.0 credit courses from the wide range of second- and
third-year courses available in UCL English (excluding Critical Commentary and
Analysis), listed here: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate">https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate</a>. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Year Three</strong></p>
<p class="p"><span class="underline">Greek and
Latin Department courses:</span> <br />1.0 credit in Latin at a level appropriate to your previous experience

<br />Latin and English extended essay

<br />Further courses from Greek and Latin, either in the original or in translation
<br /> <span class="underline">English Department courses:</span> <br /> You will select two 1.0 credit courses from the wide range of second- and
third-year courses available in UCL English (excluding Critical Commentary and
Analysis), listed here: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate">https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/current/undergraduate</a>. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Learning</strong></p>
<p class="p">You will be
taught through lectures, seminars and small-group work. Some courses will
involve student presentations. You will be assigned a Personal Tutor in both
departments, with whom you will review your progress on a regular basis. </p>
<p class="p">In the English
Department students will be producing two tutorial essays a term (one for each
of their English courses) for one-to-one tutorials with their Personal Tutor. A
mark based on tutorial essays and on oral performance in tutorials will be
awarded at the end of each term. These marks do not contribute to
combined-studies students' final degree profiles, but completion of the
tutorial essays is required for the successful completion of the
English component of the course. </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Assessment</strong></p>
<p class="p">The course will
be examined by a mixture of essays, end-of-year examinations, and a compulsory
final-year extended essay based on supervised independent research (overseen by
the Greek and Latin Department). Some Latin-language courses involve in-class
tests and grammar quizzes. 
 

The English component consists of six written papers, two per year. Courses
will be examined by written examination at the end of the year in which they
are taught. Students may choose to write one Course Essay of not more than
8,000 words long in place of one three-hour desk examination, either in their
second or third year. (Please note that as the Literary Linguistics and Literary
Representation and History of Homosexuality courses are both examined by Course
Essay, only one of these courses can be chosen as part of the Latin and English
BA.)</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 


<h2 class="heading">MA in English Linguistics</h2>








<h4 class="heading">Programme Convenor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/rachele-de-felice" target="_self">Dr Rachele de Felice</a></h4>






<h4 class="heading"></h4>




<h2 class="heading"> </h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>





<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/24Apr2009_029.jpg" width="1280" height="854" alt="1" class="xl-image" title="1" />
<h2 class="heading">Introduction</h2>





<p class="p">Explore how the
English language works and grow as a researcher on the UCL MA in English
Linguistics. Students on our MA programme are taught by experts in the fields
of grammar, morphology and semantics, phonetics and phonology, pragmatics
and discourse analysis, and corpus linguistics. We focus on
developing your research skills, with plenty of opportunities to
discuss your work, from class presentations to regular one-to-one
tutorials. You'll be based in Bloomsbury, the heart of London, just
minutes away from the British Library and the British Museum. </p>
<p class="p">

The 2017/18
programme consists of four main units (Modern English Grammar,
English Corpus Linguistics OR English in Use, Research
Methodology, and a range of Options), and a dissertation.</p>
<article class="blurb">

    <div class="blurb--video pull-left videopulled">
        <div class=" video-wrap ">
	        <iframe frameborder="0" allowfullscreen=""
                 src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/9ps0QBIOJG8"></iframe>
	        
        </div>
    </div>

    <div class="blurb__body">
        <h1 class="blurb__title"></h1>
        <p></p>

    </div>
</article>


<h3 class="heading"> </h3>




<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Modern English Grammar</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">This course
offers a comprehensive overview of the grammar of contemporary English. During
the first term we start with the basic building blocks of word classes, phrases
and clauses, as well as grammatical functions. During the second term we
discuss more complex syntactic structures. A major feature of the course is
that students will be trained to apply the principles of syntactic
argumentation. <br /></p>
<p class="p">This
30-credit course is compulsory for all students. It is taught in two-hour long
weekly seminars over two terms, and is assessed by a three-hour written
exam. <br /></p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/grammar">Reading List for Modern English Grammar 2016-17</a></p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/4131076475_82e7a9e01d_b.jpg" width="1024" height="681" alt="books2" class="xl-image" title="books2" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Research Methodology</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">The main
aim of this course is to train students in a range of practical research
skills, allowing them to perform self-directed research in linguistics,
from identifying sources of evidence and designing experiments, to evaluating
empirical results, engaging critically and integrating results with existing
literature. During the first term we discuss topics such academic writing,
data collection, and quantitative and qualitative research. The second
term includes statistics for linguistics, and a set of four sessions focused on
developing your dissertation work from first ideas to well-formed reserach
proposal. </p>
<p class="p">This
30-credit course is compulsory for all students. It is taught in two-hour
long weekly seminars over two terms, and is assessed by a portfolio of written
work.</p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/mael" width="3000" height="1688" alt="mael" class="xl-image" title="mael" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Pathways: English Corpus Linguistics and English in Use</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Students choose to specialise in either Corpus
Linguistics or English in Use after one term of seminars. Both
30-credit courses are taught in two-hour long weekly seminars over two
terms, and are assessed by a 6,000 word Course Essay on a topic of the
student's choice. <br /></p>
<p class="p">Click on the headings for full reading lists.<br /></p>



<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/corpus">English Corpus Linguistics</a></h4>



<p class="p">This course teaches the theory and
practice of corpus linguistics in English language research and
applications. Two state-of-art fully-grammatically parsed corpora of
spoken and written English developed at UCL, ICE-GB and DCPSE, are used as
exemplars to teach the course in depth, in the first term. In the second term
these resources are explored along with a range of contemporary corpora, to
illustrate the breadth of corpus linguistics research performed today.  </p>
<p class="p">Students will acquire
a thorough understanding of corpus linguistics research methods in (for
example) syntax, semantics, pragmatics and lexicography.</p>



<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/eiu">English in
Use</a> </h4>



<p class="p">This course looks at how speakers of
English use language directly and indirectly to achieve
communicative goals, and introduces students to the main theories of
pragmatics, different approaches to Politeness and Impoliteness Theory, as
well as topics ranging from forensic linguistics to world Englishes. Students
develop the skills to apply corpus analysis tools to investigate and
describe pragmatic and discourse phenomena, and to related what is studied to
real-world examples of language in use.</p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="xl-image" title="dictionary" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Topics in English Linguistics</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">This module is assessed by a compulsory
three-hour written exam. It covers a range of topics in English linguistics,
and in the exam students will be required to answer questions on <strong>two</strong> of
these topics. Options typically include:</p>



<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/englishwords">English Words  </a></h4>



<p class="p">
This  one-term option course considers various aspects of the lexicon
of  English, including the structure and meaning of words and how
this  changes, where new words come from, and social aspects of word use.
We will discuss topics  in morphology, lexical semantics and the history
of English, and take a  detailed look at the 'life stories' of some
English words.</p>



<h4 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/phonetics">Phonetics and Phonology</a></h4>



<p class="p">This one-term option course will provide
students with a basic understanding of articulatory phonetics and the ways
in which sounds are produced; a thorough grounding in the phonetics and
phonology of spoken English; an introduction to the main issues in the
phonology of English; and the practical skills of phonetic transcription.</p>



<h4 class="heading">Literary Linguistics  </h4>



<p class="p">This two-term course foregrounds the
relationship between language and literary and non-literary texts, and
considers language use from particular perspectives. In classes we will
discuss approaches from within stylistics and discourse analysis,
and examine the ways in which specific linguistic choices create
variations in style and meaning. The questions of what makes a text, and what
makes a 'literary' text, will be explored; we will go on to explore
topics including the difference between spoken and written texts, features
of language such as deixis and metaphor, and the language of particular authors
including Milton and Henry James. <br /></p>



<h4 class="heading"> 

History of the English Language</h4>



<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="xl-image" title="books3" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Dissertation</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">The final dissertation is a very important
component of the course. It consists of 10,000 words and students work on it
over the summer vacation. Several weeks of the Spring Term Research Methodology
sessions are devoted to workshops helping students develop their dissertation
plans. </p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/babel.jpg" width="940" height="421" alt="babel" class="xl-image" title="babel" />
</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>



<h2 class="heading">Curriculum and Assessment</h2>





<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/Library_0045.jpg" width="1280" height="854" alt="lib2" class="xl-image" title="lib2" /><p class="p"> Students are principally taught through seminars and
tutorials. Over the year they write a number of essays, and they do
presentations during the spring term. They have access to the Survey of English
Usage (see below), and are taught how to make use of its resources for their
dissertations.</p>
<p class="p">Forms of assessment for each module are given above.</p>

<h2 class="heading">The Survey of English Usage</h2>





<p class="p"> The
Department of English Language and Literature houses the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/english-usage"><strong>Survey
of English Usage</strong></a> (SEU), an unparalleled resource for research into the
grammatical repertoire of mature educated native speakers of English. The SEU
houses several corpora (large collections of authentic spoken and written
texts). Among them are the British component of the International
Corpus of English and the Diachronic
Corpus of Present-Day English, both of which can be explored using
innovative search software. Many important studies of the grammar, semantics
and lexis of present-day English are based on SEU material. Among them are the <em>Comprehensive
Grammar of the English Language</em> (Quirk et al. 1985), which
is recognised internationally as one of the standard reference grammars for
English, and the <em>Oxford Modern English
Grammar</em> (Aarts 2011).</p>
<p class="p"> Students
at UCL have a wide range of library resources at their disposal both on campus
and online. There are also several outstanding libraries in the near vicinity
of UCL, including the British Library and the University of London Library.</p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-spine-colors-pastel-159828.jpg" width="2970" height="1632" alt="booksbottom" class="xl-image" title="booksbottom" />
<h2 class="heading">Frequently Asked Questions</h2>











<div id="accordion2">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">What are the application requirements?</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Applications are welcome from candidates who have at least a
second class Honours degree in English language or literature, or in
linguistics, or an overseas equivalent. Some prior knowledge of English
language studies (specifically English grammar) is expected for the programme. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Can I do the course part-time?</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Part-time
students take the Modern English Grammar course in their first
year, together with one option course. During the second year they take their
second core course (either <strong>English Corpus Linguistics</strong> or <strong>English Language in Use</strong>), as well as a
second option course. The dissertation will be written during the summer of the
second year of study. Part-time students will be encouraged to work on their
dissertations over the summer following their first year. Please note that if
you intend to work, your employer will need to allow you to work flexibly, as
it will not be possible to make special timetable arrangements for part-time
students. Please also note that there are restrictions on non-EU students
applying for part-time places.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">What is the difference between the MA in English Linguistics and the MA in Linguistics (MAL)?</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> There
are important differences between the MA in English Linguistics (MAEL) and the
MA in Linguistics (MAL). First, the former is based in the English Department
while the MA in Linguistics is based in the Division of Psychology and Language
Sciences. From the point of view of content the MAEL focuses on the English
language, and has a more descriptive outlook than the theoretically-oriented
MAL, which does not have an exclusive focus on any particular language <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">What opportunities are there for further research?</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Students
who have obtained good results for their MA examinations may be considered for
the MPhil/PhD programme, subject to places being available. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>


<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>

<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading">Student Testimonials</h2>





<p class="p">&quot;I started
my MAEL programme in 2014, which was also the starting point of my
lifelong ambition. I attended all compulsory and optional courses
since they are so interesting and are never a waste of time! As a
non-native, I also gained excellent experience in academic research and
developed great writing skills (many thanks to all tutors who gave me
tutorials). I like the subject, the courses, the staff, the department, the
school, the city, so I further my study here for a PhD degree! Legendary!&quot;</p>
<p class="p">Ai Zhong (MAEL 2014-15)
</p>
<p class="p">&quot;I did the UCL MA in
English Linguistics part-time over two years and lectures on semantics,
phonetics and grammar were the highlight of my week! It impacted my work in two
ways; I became much more aware of the language choices we make, often
inadvertently, and this improved my communication in general. Since graduating,
I have also set up a new division of my PR business, Word Savvy, which helps
business people to think about their written and spoken communication. I would
definitely recommend this MA to others. It’s fascinating and has brought great
benefits to my working life.&quot;</p>
<p class="p"> Kate Warwick,
Director, PR Savvy (MAEL 2013-15)<br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>

<h2 class="heading"> </h2>






<h2 class="heading"></h2>






<h2 class="heading">Academic Staff Participating in the
Programme</h2>





<p class="p"> <strong> </strong></p>
<ul class="disc">
<li><strong><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/bas-aarts" target="_self">Professor Bas Aarts</a>,</strong> Professor of English
     Linguistics and Director of the Survey of English Usage, author of <em>Small
     Clauses in English</em> (1992), <em>English Syntax and
     Argumentation </em>(1997/2001/2008), <em>Syntactic Gradience </em>(2007), <em>Exploring
     Natural Language</em> (2002, with Gerald Nelson and Sean
     Wallis), <em>Oxford Modern English Grammar </em>(2011), and
     the <em>Oxford Dictionary of English Grammar </em>(2014);
     co-editor of <em>The Verb in Contemporary English: Theory and Description</em> (1995,
     with Charles F. Meyer), of <em>Fuzzy Grammar: a Reader</em> (2004,
     with David Denison, Evelien Keizer and Gergana Popova), <em>The Handbook of
     English Linguistics </em>(2006, with April McMahon), and of <em>The Verb Phrase in English: Investigating
     Recent Language Change with Corpora </em>(2013). Aarts is a Founding Editor
     of the Cambridge University Press journal <em>English Language and
     Linguistics</em>.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/kathryn-allan" target="_self"><strong>Dr Kathryn Allan</strong></a>, Senior Lecturer
     in English, author of <em>Metaphor and Metonymy: a Diachronic Approach</em> (2009),
     editor (with M. Winters and H. Tissari) of <em>Contributions to
     Historical Cognitive Linguistics: Syntax and Semantics </em>(2010),
     editor of <em>Current Methods in Historical Semantics </em>(2011,
     with J. Robinson), and a number of journal publications.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/rachele-de-felice" target="_self"><strong>Dr Rachele De Felice</strong></a>, Teaching
     Fellow; author of <em>Data-Driven Pragmatics: a Framework for Speech Acts </em>(forthcoming
     2014), and a number of journal articles. MA Convenor, MA English Linguistics.</li>
<li><a href="https://iris.ucl.ac.uk/iris/browse/profile?upi=SAWAL93" target="_self"><strong>Sean Wallis</strong></a>, Senior Research Fellow, Survey of English Usage,
     programmer of the ICECUP corpus exploration software, technical supervisor
     of ICE-GB and DCPSE, co-author, with Gerald Nelson and Bas Aarts, of Exploring Natural Language (2002), co-editor, with Bas Aarts,
     Geoffrey Leech and Joanne Close, of <em>The Verb Phrase in English:
     Investigating Recent Language Change with Corpora</em> (2013), and author of many journal
     articles and book chapters on Corpus Linguistics methodology and
     statistics. </li>
</ul>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/UCL-2Nov2016_027.jpg" width="1280" height="854" alt="trees" class="xl-image" title="trees" />

<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

    href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-english-linguistics/edit"><img class="zero-bottom lazy" height="10" width="10" alt="Edit Icon" title="Edit Content" src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/img/blank.gif" data-src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/images/edit.gif" id="edit_button"></a></span>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">MA English: Issues in Modern Culture</h1>
<p class="p"><strong>Programme Convenor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/people/matthew-sperling">Dr Matthew Sperling</a><br /><br /></strong></p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/Front_QuadChristmas_99_5.jpg" width="1280" height="836" alt="frontquad" class="xl-image" title="frontquad" /><p class="p">The English Department offers a one-year MA English degree, focusing on 'Issues in Modern Culture'. </p>
<p class="p">The 2017/18 programme consists of three main units (Authors, Contexts, and a wide range of Options), and then a dissertation:<br /></p>






<div id="issuesaccordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Authors</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/authors.jpg" width="1754" height="1240" alt="authors" class="xl-image" title="authors" /><p class="p">This course orchestrates close reading
 and discussions of some of the nineteenth- and twentieth-century 
British, French and American writers who most strikingly ‘made it new’. <br /></p>
<p class="p">Authors taught on this strand of the programme in the coming session will include: <strong>Gustave Flaubert, </strong><strong>James Joyce, </strong><strong>Jules Laforgue, T.S. Eliot, </strong><strong>Virginia Woolf, </strong><strong>D.H. Lawrence, </strong><strong>Elizabeth Bowen, Sylvia Townsend Warner, Willa Cather, </strong><strong>Samuel Beckett, </strong><strong>Elizabeth
 Bishop, Ralph Ellison, Alfred Hitchcock,Sylvia Plath, Bob Dylan, 
Patricia Highsmith, Toni Morrison, Alan Hollinghurst, David Simon (The Wire), and 
David Foster Wallace.  </strong><br /><br /><em>This course is compulsory for all students enrolled in the Issues in Modern Culture MA.</em></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Contexts</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/contexts.jpg" width="1754" height="1240" alt="contexts" class="xl-image" title="contexts" /><p class="p">This course, which is taught in the autumn term, explores the 
relationship between modern culture and the city from the 1860s to the 
present day. It does so by reading literature and other art forms 
(ranging from the high-brow to the popular) in the context of a broad 
range of societal, philosophical, and technological developments.<br /><br />The following topics will be covered by the <em>Contexts </em>strand of the programme in the coming session: <strong>Modernity and the City</strong>, <strong>Psychogeography, The Body and Technology, Class and the City, Mysterious Cities, The Harlem Renaissance, Hollywood Fiction, </strong><strong>Queer Fictions and the City, </strong><strong>Species of Spaces, and Catastrophe </strong></p>
<p class="p"><em>Although the vast majority of students do take Contexts, it may be replaced with another 30 credit course taught elsewhere in UCL.</em></p>
<p class="p"><em>Click <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/contextsreadinglist" target="_self">here </a>for an indicative Contexts reading list.</em><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Options</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> During <em>Options (t</em>aught 
in the Spring term), students will each choose two sets of seminars, each
 five weeks long. These options will explore specific periods, movements
 or thematic concerns of related works of literature or films. </p>
<p class="p">The department 
will offer six sets of Options in the spring term. Students on the MA 
Issues in Modern Culture take two of these optional courses, which 
change every year. <em><br /></em></p>
<p class="p"><em>Options</em> seminars for spring 2017 include: <strong><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Cultures of Offence: Literature in a Liberal Age</a>; <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Modern Sex</a>; <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Contemporary Poetry</a>; <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Inventions of Cinema</a>; <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Global Anglophone Fiction</a>; <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/prospective-students/ma-issues-in-modern-culture/options2017">Afrofuturism</a>.  <br /></strong></p>
<p class="p">Options in previous years have included: <strong>21st Century Fiction; Modernist Days (and Nights); Cultures of
 Chance: Accident, Error and Catastrophe in Literature from 1960; 
Marxist Aesthetics; Counterfeit Culture: Authenticity and Originality
 in American Literature; </strong><strong>American Counter-Culture; Modernism and History; Arts in the Anthropocene</strong>; <strong>Post-War American Poetry</strong>; <strong>Joyce Amongst the Modernists; Detective Fictions.  </strong></p>
<p class="p">Each option will be worth 8.25% or 15 credits. <br /></p>
<p class="p"><em>Students may choose to replace Options with papers taught outside the Department.</em></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Dissertation</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> The <em>Dissertation </em>is 12,000
 words long. It is worth 60 credits, or 33% of the final mark. Students 
will be allotted a supervisor who will discuss their initial proposal. </p>
<p class="p">The Dissertation is a perfect preperation for students who wish to continue to doctoral study, but also works well for students who wish to complete a smaller stand-alone project.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Application Requirements</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Candidates for admission to the programme should 
normally have at least a good upper second-class honours BA degree in 
English, or its overseas equivalent. This is, however, a 
popular course, and each year we are unfortunately forced to reject a 
number of well-qualified candidates.</p>
<p class="p">Most students 
on the course have BA degrees (or have majored) in English, but we will also consider 
applicants holding a degree in another subject, although tutors will 
need to see obvious commitment to the study of English Literature and a 
strong academic background for these applicants to be successful.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Application Process</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> We receive most applications between January and March of the proposed 
year of entry. The deadline for applications to be completed is<strong> 28th July</strong><strong> 2017</strong>, but we would encourage students to apply before this in order to ensure that places are still available. References should also have been uploaded by both referees before this deadline.<br /></p>
<p class="p">Candidates
 will be asked to provide transcripts of their academic record with 
their application, and the tutors will primarily be making decisions 
over whether or not an applicant is admitted on their previous academic 
achievements, their personal statement, and their references.</p>
<p class="p">Applicants are not interviewed. Candidates are not required to enclose a writing sample with the initial application. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Part Time Students</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> We welcome applications for part-time study of this course, as well as full-time. Part-time students take the <em>Contexts </em>and <em>Options </em>strands in their first year, and <em>Authors </em>in the second year. The dissertations of part-time students are submitted at the end of their second year. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>




<h3 class="heading">Further Information</h3>




<p class="p">For further information about this course, or about anything else UCL-related, please email the Admissions and Postgraduate Administrator, Clare Stainthorp: <a href="mailto:c.stainthorp@ucl.ac.uk" target="_self">c.stainthorp@ucl.ac.uk</a></p>


<h3 class="heading">Apply Online</h3>




<p class="p">A link to the application from on the main UCL website can be found at the bottom of this page: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/apply" target="_self">https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/graduate/apply</a></p>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/quadsummer" width="502" height="319" alt="Quad Summer" class="decorative xl-image" title="Quad Summer" />

<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Indicative Contexts Reading List 2016/2017</h1>



<h4 class="heading">1.MODERNITY AND THE CITY</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Charles Baudelaire, ‘Tableaux Parisiens’ (Poems LXXXVI-CIII) from Les Fleurs du Mal, ed. by E. Starkie (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1959). </li>
<li>Sophie Calle, Double Game (Violette Editions, 2007)</li>
<li>Charles Baudelaire, ‘The Painter of Modern Life’ in The Painter of Modern Life and other essays (London: Phaidon, 2001).Walter Benjamin, ‘The Flâneur’ from Charles Baudelaire: A Lyric Poet in the Era of High Capitalism (London: Verso Books).</li>
<li>Rachel Bowlby, ‘Walking, Women and Writing: Virginia Woolf as flâneuse’, in Still Crazy After All these Years (London: Routledge, 1992).</li>
<li>Mary Ann Caws, The Surrealist Look: An Erotics of Encounter (MIT Press, 1997) </li>
<li>Lauren Elkin, Flâneuse: the (Feminine) Art of Walking in Cities (London: Chatto &amp; Windus, 2016)</li>
<li>F.T. Marinetti, ‘The Founding and Manifesto of Futurism’, in Apollonio, Umbro, ed. Documents of 20th Century Art: Futurist Manifestos. Brain, Robert, R.W. Flint, J.C. Higgitt, and Caroline Tisdall, trans. (New York: Viking Press, 1973).</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">2.PSYCHOGEOGRAPHY</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Alan Moore &amp; Eddie Campbell, From Hell (1996; Knockabout, 2006)</li>
<li>Selections from Oscar Zarate (ed.), It’s Dark in London (Self Made Hero, 2012)</li>
<li>Patrick Keiller, London and Robinson in Space (1994; BFI DVD, 2012)</li>
<li>Guy Debord, The Society of the Spectacle (1967; Rebel Press, 1992)</li>
<li>Stewart Home, Mind Invaders: A Reader in Psychic Warfare, Cultural Sabotage and Semiotic Terrorism (Serpent's Tail, 1997)</li>
<li>Patrick Keiller, The View from the Train: Cities and Other Landscapes (Verso Books, 2014)</li>
<li>Will Self and Ralph Steadman, Psychogeography (Bloomsbury, 2007)</li>
<li>Iain Sinclair, London Orbital (Penguin, 2003)</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">3.TECHNOLOGY  AND THE BODY </h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>J.G. Ballard, Crash (London: Fourth Estate, 2014)</li>
<li>J.G. Ballard, The Atrocity Exhibition, first published 1970, rev.edn. (London, HarperPerennial, 2006)</li>
<li>Marc Augé, Non-places, John Howe, trans. (London; New York: Verso, 1995).</li>
<li>Nicholas Daly, Literature, Technology and Modernity: 1860—2000 (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2004).</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">4.CLASS AND THE CITY</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Zadie Smith, NW (2012)</li>
<li>Ben Lerner, 10:04 (Granta, 2015)</li>
<li>Gary Day,Class (The New Critical Idiom) (Routledge, 2001)</li>
<li>Lawrence Driscoll, Evading Class in Contemporary British Literature (Palgrave, 2011)</li>
<li>Writers For The 99%, Occupying Wall Street: The Inside Story Of An Action That Changed America (Scribe Publications, 2012) </li>
<li>Philip Tew (ed),Reading Zadie Smith: The First Decade and Beyond (Bloomsbury, 2013)</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">5.THE HARLEM RENAISSANCE</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Jean Toomer, Cane (1923; Norton Critical Editions, 2011)Langston Hughes, Collected Poems (Vintage, 1995)</li>
<li>Houston A. Baker, Modernism and the Harlem Renaissance (University of Chicago Press, 1989)</li>
<li>Langston Hughes, The Big Sea (Knopf, 1940)</li>
<li>Alain Locke (ed.), The New Negro (1925; Touchstone, 1999)</li>
<li>Richard Powell (ed.), Rhapsodies in Black: Art of the Harlem Renaissance (University of California Press, 1997)</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">6. MYSTERIOUS CITIES</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Edgar Allan Poe, ‘The Murders in the Rue Morgue’, ‘The Mystery of Marie Roget’, ‘The Purloined Letter’</li>
<li>Arthur Conan Doyle, The Valley of Fear</li>
<li>Chandler, Raymond, ‘The Simple Art of Murder’, in Pearls Are a Nuisance</li>
<li>Knight, Stephen, Crime Fiction 1800-2000 (2004)</li>
<li>Strabnick, Amy Gilman, The Mysterious Death of Mary Rogers (1995)</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">7. QUEER FICTIONS AND THE CITY</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Gore Vidal, The City and the Pillar (1948)</li>
<li>Andrew Holleran,Dancer from the Dance (1978)</li>
<li>Oscar Moore, A Matter of Life and Sex (1991)</li>
<li>Edmund White, The Farewell Symphony (1997)</li>
<li>Les Brookes, Gay Male Fiction Since Stonewall: Ideology, Conflict, and Aesthetics</li>
<li> (New York: Routledge, 2009)</li>
<li>Guy Davidson, Queer Commodities: Contemporary US Fiction, Consumer Capitalism, and Gay and Lesbian Subcultures (New York: Palgrave, 2012)</li>
<li>Stevens, Hugh, ed. The Cambridge Companion to Gay and Lesbian Writing (Cambridge: Cambridge UP, 2011).</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">8. HOLLYWOOD FICTION</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>David Lynch, Mulholland Drive (2002)</li>
<li>F.S. Fitzgerald, The Last Tycoon,  (Penguin Classics: London, 2010).</li>
<li>N. West, The Day of the Locust,  (Penguin: London, 2006).</li>
<li>M. Davis, City of Quartz: Excavating the Future in Los Angeles, (Verso: London; New York, 2006).</li>
<li>J. Baudrillard, Simulacra and Simulation, (University of Michigan Press: Ann Arbor, 1994).</li>
<li>J. Fante, Ask the Dust, (Black Sparrow: Santa Barbara, 1980).</li>
<li>E. Waugh, The Loved One: an Anglo-American Tragedy, (Penguin: London, 2011).</li>
<li>R. Chandler, The Long Goodbye, (Hamish Hamilton: London, 2009).</li>
<li>B. Wilder, Sunset Boulevard,  (University of California Press: Berkeley, Calif.; London, 1999).</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">9.CATASTROPHE</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>William Basinski, The Disintegration Loops</li>
<li>Tom McCarthy, Remainder (London: Vintage, 2005)</li>
<li>Maurice Blanchot, The Writing of the Disaster, trans. Ann Smock (Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press, 1986)</li>
<li>Simon Critchley and Tom McCarthy, ‘Derail Yourself’, The International Necronautical </li>
<li>Society, ‘Declaration on the Notion of the Future,’ The Believer, November/December 2010.</li>
<li>Ross Hamilton, Accident (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2007)</li>
<li>Paul Virilio, The Original Accident (Cambridge: Polity, 2007)</li>
</ul>



<h4 class="heading">10. SPECIES OF SPACES</h4>



<ul class="circle">
<li>Georges Perec, ‘Species of Spaces’ (1974), in Species of Spaces and Other Pieces</li>
<li> (Penguin), ed. and trans. John Sturrock</li>
<li>J. G. Ballard, ‘Billennium’ (1961) and ‘The Enormous Space’ (1989), in The Complete Short Stories of J. G. Ballard (Fourth Estate)</li>
<li>Harold Pinter, The Room (1957) and The Caretaker(1960) </li>
<li>Georges Perec, Life: A User’s Manual, trans. David Bellos (1987)</li>
<li>Clive Donner (dir.), The Caretaker (1963) </li>
<li>Richard Curson Smith (dir.), Home (2003) </li>
<li>Our House: The Representation of Domestic Space in Modern Culture (Rodopi, 2006)</li>
<li>Chiara Briganti and Kathy Mezei (ed.), The Domestic Space Reader</li>
<li> (University of Toronto, 2012)</li>
</ul>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>

                    </div>
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Options 2017</h1>
<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/options.jpg" width="1754" height="1240" alt="Options 2017" class="xl-image" title="Options 2017" /><p class="p"><strong>Afrofuturism: Race, Utopia and Science Fiction 
</strong></p>
<p class="p">A defining
image of pulp science fiction is the moment when a fleet of unfamiliar ships
arrive, seemingly from nowhere, pale, questionably human forms disembark, and
abduct the locals. As a symbolic map of the traumas of abduction, the middle
passage, and the experience of slavery, science fiction is a form that has much
to say to African American cultural history. Why is it then, that in the minds
of many, the genre is “white as driven snow” or “a Ku Klux Klan rally”, in the
words of Charles R. Saunders? When Samuel Delany submitted excerpts from <em>Nova </em>(1968) for serial publication, he
was explicitly rejected for transgressing this colour line: “For heaven’s
sakes,” the editor wrote to his agent, “he’s got a Negro for a protagonist!
It’s a good book, but our reader’s aren’t going to be able to identify with
that…”</p>
<p class="p"> This Option explores these
marginalised works, reading Delany alongside radical poets, novelists,
filmmakers and musicians, all of whom explore the experience of being caught
“on the wrong side of the strange-looking ship that appears out of nowhere”
(Nalo Hopkinson, 2004). Starting out with the historical literature of the
middle passage, the five seminars will range through counterfactual histories
of Sub-Saharan Africa, cinematic fantasies of Egyptian interstellar technology,
and the poetics of contemporary hip hop. In so doing, we shall join Kodwo Eshun
and others in the task of assembling a host of “countermemories that contest
the colonial archive.”</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Modern Sex: Eroticism and Literary Writing 
</strong></p>
<p class="p">‘The Faustian pact, whose temptation has been
instilled in us by the deployment of sexuality, is now as follows: to exchange
life in its entirety for sex itself, for the truth and the sovereignty of sex.
Sex is worth dying for. It is in this (strictly historical) sense that sex is
indeed imbued with the death instinct. When a long while ago the West
discovered love, it bestowed on it a value high enough to make death
acceptable: nowadays it is sex that claims this equivalence, the highest of
all.’ – Michel Foucault, The History of
Sexuality: An Introduction</p>
<p class="p">This course begins with an introduction to
the study of ‘sexuality’, and asks why the late nineteenth century is so
important to the construction of modern sexual identities. The following four
seminars will consider the representation of sexuality in a wide range of
modern fiction.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Contemporary British Poetry</strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong></strong>This module – led by three of the department’s own
published poets – is designed to allow students to engage with a selection of
poetry from our contemporaries, looking in detail at a deliberately small
number of texts, but also allowing us to range widely across the current poetry
scene. The module opens with the oldest of our texts, J. H. Prynne’s High Pink on Chrome, an early long-form
poem from an avant-garde poet who has been variously celebrated and castigated
for his provocative output, leading some to style him ‘the most important
living poet’ while others describe his work as simply ‘not poetry.’ The session on Mick Imlah and Kei Miller will
explore depictions of history, the use of literary traditions, and figurations
of national identity in the work of these two poets. In Week 3, we will focus
on recent volumes by Vahni Capildeo and Vidyan Ravinthiran. Like Miller,
Capildeo is Caribbean writer now based in the UK. Her hard-to-categorise poems
reach out to her native Trinidad, sitting alongside experimental modes in
recent British poetry while not exactly being <em>of</em> them. British-born Ravinthiran grew up in Leeds to Sri Lankan
parents. In <em>Grun-tu-molani</em>, he has
crafted a first book that delights in wrong-footing the unwary reader, from its
title onwards. Beginning with questions of poetic form – what is the
significance of ‘prose’ or the ‘prosaic’ for these two poets? – our discussion will roam into matters such as
voice, race, migration, cultural hybridity, violence and the political
role of the poet. In Week 4, we will
discuss the latest collection by the philosopher Denise Riley – who by then may
have won this year’s Forward Prize, following both Imlah and Miller – described
as ‘a deeply moving document of maternal grief and loss by one of our finest writers.’
In the final week, students will be asked to present to the group their own
choice of contemporary poem, hopefully thereby introducing all of us to a wide
range of the most interesting recent writing. 
</p>
<p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong>Inventions of Cinema</strong></p>
<p class="p"><strong></strong>This option will cover nearly 120 years of cinema, from its origins to
two recent films which show that exciting work is still possible in the medium – and will
examine some of the ways cinema has found to reinvent itself.</p>
<p class="p">Week One: The Invention of Cinema: Lumières, Méliès &amp; Fritz Lang’s Metropolis
(1926)                         </p>
<p class="p">Week Two: Old and New: Jean Renoir’s The Rules of the Game (1939) &amp;
Powell &amp; Pressburger’s The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp
(1943) </p>
<p class="p">Week Three: Experimental LA Noir: John Boorman’s Point Blank (1967) &amp;
Roman Polanski’s Chinatown  
(1974)     </p>
<p class="p"> Week Four: Inside Celebrity: Billy Wilder’s Sunset Boulevard (1950) &amp;
Martin Scorsese’s The King of Comedy (1982)</p>
<p class="p">Beginnings and Endings: Boyhood (2014) &amp; Amour
(2012)  </p>
<p class="p"><strong>Cultures of Offence: Literature in a Liberal Age
</strong></p>
<p class="p">In an age in which much of the
discourse about universities – and especially about the teaching of humanities
subjects – revolves around ‘trigger warnings’ and ‘safe spaces’, this Option
will consider the various meanings of ‘offence’ as it is now routinely invoked
and explore its use as a repressive force against the freedoms of speech and
art. In a spirit of straight-talking enquiry, it will ask whether the
liberalism upon which ‘Western’ civilization so prides itself has not led to the
imposition of momentous restrictions on the very liberties for which it had
originally stood. We will discuss the importance of ‘offensive’ literature –
its role in the disarming of taboos, the shifting of values, and the
recognition of difference. In so doing, we will reflect on the fluctuating
criteria by which the worth of literature is measured. </p>
<p class="p">After an initial session devoted
to the meanings of ‘offence’ in history, examination of these complex issues
will be carried out through the study of literary texts. We will analyze the
ways in which certain pre-eminent writers, such as Salman Rushdie, J.M.
Coetzee, Philip Roth, and Michel Houellebecq, interrogate some of the
paradoxical contemporary consequences of liberalism – its role, specifically, in
the promotion of certain kinds of censorship and self-censorship.</p>
<p class="p"><strong>Global Anglophone Fiction </strong></p>
<p class="p">The years
since the mid-twentieth century have witnessed a remarkable flourishing of
English-language writing from nations that were formerly British colonies. This
course offers the opportunity to study a selection of major fictional works by
authors from Anglophone Africa, South Asia and the Caribbean, and to examine
the contemporary phenomenon of the global English novel. We will consider
questions such as: How can critical frameworks from postcolonial and
transnational studies inform our reading of these works? How are themes such as
the city, sexuality and historical trauma treated in these works, and how does
this differ from earlier works of British and American modernism? How far are
these works united by their common language and/or distinguished by their
disparate contexts and localities? And how is world writing in English packaged
for and marketed to a literary readership?</p>
<p class="p"><strong> </strong></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     <div class="content-sidebar">
                                        <div class="site-content__sidebar">


<h4 class="heading">Student Views</h4>




<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/dictionary.jpg" width="960" height="639" alt="dictionary" class="medium-image" title="dictionary" /><p class="p">&quot;The main benefit of the programme
 is definitely the one-to-one tutorial system. Students are allocated a 
different tutor each year, and although the fortnightly essays may seem a
 little heavy, the tailored feedback we receive is invaluable. The 
opportunity to discuss poems, prose, and plays with experts in their 
field is exciting for both students and their tutors.&quot;<br /></p>




<h6 class="heading">Angelica Barbe, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English  </h6>


<img src="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/english/images/books-1082942_960_720.jpg" width="960" height="643" alt="books3" class="medium-image" title="books3" /><p class="p"><br /> &quot;A degree in English also does not
mean you are limited to 'typical' careers e.g. journalism, teaching, academia
(but it's also great if this is what you want to do!) Studying English at UCL opens many doors for the future and provides you with
skills that are applicable in many different areas. <br /></p>
<p class="p">The Department is very forward-thinking, as well as being both helpful and welcoming&quot;</p>




<h6 class="heading">Ellie Pearce, Third Year Undergraduate, BA English </h6>



</div>
